reviewText: How can a game be terrible and awesome at the same time? I don't know, but that is the case here. Bugs, glitches, terrible voice acting and vanilla writing mask a large, enjoyable open world, a confusing but rewarding alchemy system, a ton of loot, and enjoyable exploration. I love this game, and when it's on sale it is an incredible value. If you like B movies and Oblivion, this is their ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child.

reviewText: One of my badges gave me a coupon for this game. Now I didn't think much of it was like 90% off so I looked and total was about a buck. And for a dollar I figured ... Cant go wrong right?  Now all I can say is Wow after over 50 hours in and hardly touching the main story.  I'm still enjoying it. One of the best dollars I have spent.

reviewText:
Okay, so I have to start my review by admitting I really enjoyed my time playing Two Worlds.  As others have said, the game is fairly glitchy, but as a long-time gamer, glitches don't ruin things for me as long as they are consistent.  In fact, learning to take advantage of those glitches used to be a big part of gaming, and I enjoyed the challenge in Two Worlds.

The game is pretty standard fare with a male hero seeking to save the hapless female (yawn), and the hack-and-slash gameplay is good.  Go kill some stuff, collect stuff, and do some quests that consist of killing stuff and collecting stuff.  It's nothing special, but I enjoyed it all the same.

The voice acting is so bad that I actually played with the game muted.  That was a new experience.

I was having fun, exploring the land and doing side quests, and then I discovered something horrible.  Truly horrible.  This is the gamer's equivalent of Lovecraftian Old Ones rising from their slumber to slaughter the denizens of an innocent town...

After about 90 hours of gameplay (mostly ignoring the main quest), I discovered that certain tasks in side quests MUST NOT be completed before certain other tasks in the main quest.  Or you break your entire experience.  And the game can't progress.  And there is NO way to fix it.

...

Boo.

reviewText:
Well, after playing quite a lot and still playing I decided to recommend this game, at least to rpg funs. I am saying this because with a ton of games available today and so many on sale offers, one may easily abandon a game and go for another.
Why I like this game? It is addictive. It keeps you playing for its advantages regardless its flaws. I have a lot of games, games I go back playing like skyrim, games I do not stop until I complete them like shadow of Mordor and games I never start playing yet. Too many games, too few time. Still, two worlds is a game that I start and did not abandon nor I will anytime soon. This game has something strangely addictive. For example I abandon dark souls about mid game while been an excellent game but I am now mid-game at two worlds and I hardy spent this little time to write this, right now I prefer to enter the game and continue.
To describe this game very briefly, it is like diablo on levelling and items, like oblivion on world environment feeling and like divinity 2 on movement and combat. It also has some unique gameplay elements on its own.
What you need to know primarily is that tutorial is brief and very basic. This game needs your close attention to understand it. The first time I play I think there were major flaws and bad designs but with a second and third closer careful looks I understand that I was wrong. Once you understand how things work it is where you really get addicted. I am sure that most negative reviews comes from hasty gamers. I do not blame them, a modern game needs to have a proper tutorial, a complex game a large tutorial, this game most likely relies on the manual.
Let’s get on details(the bad stuff at the end):
The character: You only play a male human character, no females and no races. That’s it. Also your starting character is fixed, fixed attributes and fixed starting skills. You cannot start with point pool and boost what you like. However the starting skills are the basic ones and at level 1 of 10. You can level up and increase any you like. All starting skills are all you need to do all essential things and secondary actions. For example you have lock pick 1 and you can lock pick and also increase it for a better chance. You do not have alchemy skill but you can still use alchemy. Finally, playing the game and visit villages and towns will allow you to meet trainers that will teach you the level 1 of all skills eventually, so there is no skill point cost at all for level 1 skill. If for example you want to advance alchemy or water magic you do not start with, all you need is to find the appropriate trainers to get the 1st skill point by paying some money. While levelling you get 5 attribute points and one or two skill points, usually one. You may also get one skill point before you level up but I have not yet figure out when, the game has many good secrets. You can also permanently increase attributes using alchemy even without skill 1, if you find the proper ingredients. In other words the game is rewarding for the good and smart player offering more than the standard gain experience and fixed level up procedure. Two level 10 characters for example may be different, one may be even 40% stronger from extra attributes and skills alone.
The gear and items: Items are much like diablo, leveled items and many auxiliary items, consumables and especially ingredients. The only disadvantage here if it is one is that there are too many items. Not just leveled, too many items. Perhaps the greatest variety on gear I have ever seen. Ready consumables are just what is needed. Ingredients are plenty and not only herbs but also parts from animals and various minerals. There are also gems as consumables to add different types of damage to weapons, traps to set, spell cards and spell boosters and few standard items like the teleport stone and quest items.
One unique gameplay element here is that you can enhance any gear item, weapon or armor with another piece of item of the same type. Items have a special attribute called ‘class’ which is usually one. If you have a short sword for example and find another one you can drag and drop it one another and you will now have a class 2 short sword which of course is a little better, doing more damage in that case. This is a very good thing and very useful, as it allows you to use trivial equipment to avoid buying everything from the store at every couple of levels or so, or live and die by drop chance alone. For example I used a Grom Shield that happened to be a very common item groms carry and drop so I end up finding about 30 or so, effectively had a class 30 simple grom shield with a parry number high enough to keep me up to level 10 or so. Then there were better shields to buy and enemies no longer often carry that shield, so it was time to change. Spell cards also stack. Add a second and third and so on card of the same spell and the spell becomes stronger, requiring more mana however. Finally gems can be placed on a weapon for extra damage and you can put as many as you like as long as they are of the same type, e.g. rubies that add fire damage.
Money and trading: Surprisingly money are always needed here, and the game offers a fair amount of money. The trading is active to this game. You always earn cash and you always have reasons to spent, and not on consumables exclusively. I’d rather say you may spent for making your hero more powerful. Enemies either drop inventory with a fair amount of gold and random items or a single standard automatic pickup, like the wolf drops a wolf heart which is an ingredient.  Anything may drop but specific items have better sources to be harvested and animals and beast always drop standard ingredient item instead of inventory. All except single pickups are level depended, chests, enemy inventories and shops. You are bored looking for ingredients that increase your stats permanently? No problem, pay some attention to mage shops and after a certain level you definitely come across to buy.
Enemies: Good variety of enemies, large size enemies are really deadly and not level depended, leveled enemies are logical like bandits; they got stronger but not as much as you.
Classes: The 3 archetypes work well, fighter, mage and archer/thief that is. Hybrids also work well. There is depth on each single archetype, fighting style and weapons for fighters, magic schools for mages and lots of choices to master for an archer/thief.
The story is interesting, the world is very good at least. The soundtrack is almost perfect.

Now the bad stuff:
The back-jump. Honestly I hated that. In my opinion it ruins melee. I do not even assigned it to a button. The game is much better without. Again, my opinion.
The dialogues. Not sure what English dialect that is but it is strange until you get used to it. Also some times are almost childish, some other times are very mature. Your hero speaks quite well though.
The NPC characters. Quite average.
The spells. They are lots and great and come in form of cards that stack and extra spell booster cards (more damage, less mana etch). However you may have 3 spells with booster cards (that also stack), the others need some special way to be placed on your custom hot bar, first on the spell amulet and then on the hot bar. No big deal but somewhat annoying.

reviewText:
Pros:
1. Great Open world to explore and discover stuff
2. One of those games that the more you play, the better your guy gets, no cap
3. Gameplay is fun
4. Quests aren't repetitive
Cons:
1. Acting is TERRIBLE
2. Graphics are not the best, its a pretty old game after all
3. Quests are annoying at times, like i said, acting is really bad
4. Can get quite annoying

Reason for recommendation:
While the acting is terrible and the quests can be annoying, I personally enjoyed it just cause you can go out and just level up endlessly and the gear has a fun upgrading system, you can get more of the same item and combine them to make it better, but it will still be the same item. So, say you take out a tower, and like every other guy had the same weapon. You can then take all the weapons and combine them together and get a weapon that may just be better than what you're using. Worst comes to worst you can always sell it and not worry about having to carry around 15+ weapons to get your gold. I have always enjoyed a game that has endless upgrading. This one is enjoyable too if you can get past the terrible acting and just do your own thing.

reviewText:
I really like this game but it is super rough around the edges. Mouth sync is non existent, graphics are dated, quite a few glitches, and small mechanic issues. I won't lie and say you won't notice them, because you will. However, this is now the third time I have completed this game, and I still give it a good rating. I have more fun every time I run through it.

I love this series so much, and it sucks that they have stopped adding to it. This game has a great charm to it. Everyone speaks in old English and it just sounds nice. The second one is all around better, but no other game has had that charm that this game has.

This game honestly has a lot going for it. The experience system is nice and even. The skill building is cool. The mobs are varied. The armor upgrade system is awesome. The area looks good and is quite diverse. If you get past the problems, there is a real gem here.

I am fully recommending this game. Love it!
voteText: 78 of 93 people (84%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I can recommend this game. But to be honest...just barely!
+ Huge World to discover and it is open world from the start
+ Very fast loading screens
+ It definitely has a certain charm and overall I liked the game
- There are so many areas you can just ignore because theres nothing to do there. In my personal experience I found the southern part of the map so unpleasant that I just rode my horse past all enemies to get to a certain place as fast as possible.

+ Environments look nice, full of trees, vegetation, wild animals and other enemies. The water looked extremely good for a game that old.
+ A lot of different enemy types!
- The environments also look very round and generic, there are almost no rocks or cliffs in this game

+ The cities and villages are filled with many many NPCs
- All the NPCs look similar and it is hard to recognice those who actually advance the plot.
- Most of them just say the same thing and are just there to fill the city...useless!

+ Teleporters are scattered all over the map to make travelling faster. Without much loading time.
- Most of the times the teleporters are also quite far away from where you want to go. I recommend planting a mobile teleporter next to some merchants in one of the cities so you can save some time because you will want to sell your stuff frequently.

+ Merchants have no limited amount of gold, so you can sell them all the stuff you want.
- Your Inventory has a limit. At some point your strength doesn't increase the carry weight any more.

+ Some of the cities are huge and very impressive
- They are also too big and you have to run through them to get to an important NPC or merchant
- Also they lack verticality as there are no towers or walls to be climbed, the hero can also not climb any ladders, they are just for decoration

+ Horses for longer journeys are very useful. They are much faster and you can find them in many places.
- The controls for horses are very stiff. You will get stuck in trees, rocks and they wont go up or down any steep landslides. Horses do not teleport with you and the function to whistle for your horse is useless when being further than 10 meters away from it.

+ The combat animations look great
+ There are a lot of different ways to attack: Magic, Bows, Clubs, Staffs, Swords, Daggers, Axes... . Some two-handed and you can dual-wield.
+ You can enchant your weapons with (an unlimited amount of?) gems of the same type making them more and more powerful. I have literally used all of my fire-gems on one weapon and it was extremely strong and I could add even more fire gems after that.
+ It is very satisfying to kill an enemy with a two handed club because they will sometimes fly all over the place.
- It also feels very stiff to fight. You will constantly miss enemies. There is no way of actively blocking an attack (at least I didnt find it).
- I am sure I am not the only one to be very annoyed by the enemies with bow and arrow. It usually goes like this: Attack a group of enemies, the ones with swords will die first because they are in close combat. The archers are in the background shooting at you. You run at them to kill them. Before you can swing at them they already turned around and ran further away. You run at them to kill them. Before you can swi......x3 I've chased archers across the map like this so many times.
-The framerate seems to go down during battles

+ A huge amount of different armours and robes, rings and amulets. They can also be stacked when you find identical items. It is very motivating to be on the lookout for better equipment.
- The high level armours wont allow you to swim, use your bow or dual wield. Why not?
- There is a river flowing across the world. I wondered: I have an armour which doesn#t allow me to swim. So I ran towards the water and....the hero just walked to the other side of the river...under water! (which is also MUCH faster than swimming!)

+ A large selection of skills to level up. And a lot of different spells.
- Swimming skill is useless. Don't waste any points on it. There was no situation at all where I was required to swim anywhere.
- Sneaking skill is useless too, as is pickpocket skill. You wont have any money problems in this game.
- If you want to use the best armour in the game, don't level up your arching skills, because those armours can't be used with bow and arrow.
- Horse riding skill is useless. The few times I did use horses I just used them to travel faster and get off them as soon as possible :)
- There is a skill to de-horse enemies....I have not seen an enemy riding a horse.

+ You can also stack your magic spells to make them more powerful.
- Projectiles are very slow and will often miss their target when it isn't either standing still or moving towards you.

+ Cool looking creatures can be summoned. They can distract enemies.
- Summoned creatures are very slow and have no perception of depth. They will miss their swing 9 times out of 10.

+ The music and sound effects are enjoyable.
- The english sync is horrible! Try to play it in another language. I played it in german and it sounds a lot better.

+The whole world is full of side quests!
+ Levelling up is fun
+ NPCs have a lot of dialogue and it's all voiced.
+ A lot of small stories help to get involved in the world
- Sometimes I skipped the dialogue because I didnt care.
- Personally I didn't find the story interesting

reviewText:
Two Worlds is an open world third person medieval fantasy role playing game that borders on a single player MMORPG. Its not just single player, there is a multi player function via network. Even if you want to just play single player, you need to setup a user name and password. I'd say that the game was designed for multi player. Its not just fighting one enemy, but packs of them and they were far too overpowered until I was 4 hours into the game. That's one of a number of bad first impressions I was given.

I was forced to run away and let two packs of enemies kill one another and then I'd loot the corpses. It became part of the game for me. If you're not into combat, you can run by any enemy no matter how large or overpowering they are. Even if a dozen enemies are following you, they'll get bored eventually. You'll always be faster even if there's no run button. You can chose your level of difficulty at the start, but never in the game. I made the mistake of going medium.

The game has a lot of dialog. In fact some banter between my character and a quest giver bordered on a novella's length. I'd watch the sun rise in the background only to have night fall during the conversation it was so long. The voice acting is stiff, slow and spoken in the old tongue. I can't call it bad voice acting, the voices are memorable, its just the speed, delivery and the mayhap
date: whenst" and archaic words that are no longer used. It was almost a point of comedy until I got used to it. With that being said

reviewText:
Lets get the bad stuff out of the way first. BUGS. HOLY MOTHER OF GOD, THEY'RE EVERYWHERE. It's like an infestation of glitches of every kind: graphical (I'll talk about that later.), gameplay, combat and some are even game-breaking. Walk up stairs,  open a chest, and never walk down the stairs again due to the magical power of floating over noble gasses gained in the 11 seconds you spent raiding the poor farmer's pantry. Luckily, the game keeps a good list of autosaves to avoid these issues.

Second biggest problem: the visuals are horrendous. I was walking through what I thought was a field of grass and happiness, when suddenly...bamboo. A whole forest of it, and I was walking through the center of the mighty wilds without even noticing. It took the game 10 minutes to process the enviroment fully. I could understand this if you were playing Mass Effect 3 on a Commodore 64, but with these extremely out-dated and pixely graphics, it should take less than 5 seconds on an average non-gaming computer.

Oh, and don't bother talking to that drunk guy in Four Stones Village. His voice acting is even worse than the cook in the army camp named Bodlo, wh speaks in 3rd person and has the voice of a pig that was injected with both steriods and female hormones.

With the bad parts aside, lets talk about why this game is actually worth the $10.00 asking price. Let's be posh and give you a list of blunt statements:

- ALMOST 600 ARMOUR SETS, each with individual pieces: helmet, gauntlets, legs, torso, and boots.
- 200 different weapons
- Decent character customization (Though more hair options would be nice, other than just the 12 flavours of short available in 9 shades of brown.)
- Very easy to pick up and play.
- Puns of Damage. And lots of them. Some of them are even tolerable!
- Large open world, with tons of shiny loot, though I wish more of it could be placed in your house...which you can't have.

Over all, the hardcore gamer will find nothing of interest here. Fans of western RPG's will find an interesting mix of complete control over your character's destiny, and terrible, game breaking bugs such as randomly dying when you pick a lock to...
A TENT? I can bloody see inside of it for the love of damn.

reviewText:
Really having a lot of fun with this 6 year old open world RPG (for the second time through), thanks to some great updates.

Patches have made the game a lot more stable, bug free, and even better looking. Sure its not perfect, but neither is Skyrim if you really think about it (backwards flying dragons FTW).

What TW does have is great visuals, deep player controlled character delopment, a lot of crafting/combining items into more powerful items,  tons of loot and a pretty good story thats fully voiced with a lot of optional side quests.

Become any hero you want to be with no classes or weird ♥♥♥ leveling requirements.

Theres 5 schools of magic with 25 spells (each) that all can be powered up and boosted, bows (with different ranges and different draw speeds) and 7 different melee type weapons (Axes 1h/2h, Pikes, Maces 1h/2h, Swords 1h/2h).

As you level up  you'll get Paramater Points to spend on 4 attributes, Strength, Vitality, Willpower and Dexterity, but you'll also get a lot of points from finding rare items and making stat increasing potions. You start with everything at 5, but it might not be long until your skills are in the 100's, the sky is the limit (might actually be 1000, not sure).

Also by gaining a level (or completing certain goals) you'll gain skill points to put into one of the games 38 skills. Like Beskering or Multiple Arrows, or sneaking and stabbing someone in the back.

Walk around the huge map or fast travel via a teleportation system that you can set and move 3 points of, or  try horse riding with mounted combat.

It's very much a complete game thats fun, and challenging, and something that YOU get to build your character in. Again, yes, it is rough around the edges... but the overall experience is definatly worth it.

reviewText: I would highly reccommend this game to anyone looking for RPG Adventure games similar to the Elder Scrolls Saga. Decent graphics considering it is from 2007. I greatly enjoy the open world format, although, sometimes inventory space is an issue, especially when hoarding materials for when you reach level 10 Alchemy (Skill initially learned from a trainer without enhancements you have ot be level 24 to max skill). So far I am 37 hours in and I think it has a Good Story line. The teleport side quest is exceedingly helpful in making sure you don't have to leave any loots behind. Slight lag when it autosaves but otherwise runs smoothly.  Biggest disappointment thus far has been the inability to pickpocket from the NPC's. Word of Advice to those interrested in this game, use caution and consult google before diving head on into using alchemy, permanent indregient aren't very easy to come by and the brewing system is not intuitive on how to best maximise thier use.

reviewText:
Don't compare this game to Oblivion. Try Gothic 1, then compare games again... or try Arx Fatalis and come back.

Two Worlds is a grand effort from a small team to try to make a game they'd want to play. A labor of love, so to speak. It's for that reason why I love the Gothic series (especially the third one).

In Two Worlds, you don't get the feel and controls of a triple A game franchise. You get handcrafted, homecooked, delicious, awkward experimentation from gamers who love games.

Remember Peter Jackson's first few movies? Would it surprise you to know that the guy who gave us all the Lord of the Rings movies started out just making random, insane films, like Dead Alive" and "Meet the Feebles"? Innovation requires risk.

Two Worlds does things a bit differently and that's what's worth taking notice of. Sure
recommended: and your main character says "Mayhap" and "Perchance" enough times in the first hour to make you want to invent time travel and murder ancient languages... but keep playing.\n\nKeep playing and discover an absolutely massive world with very

reviewText:
Oh, where to begin? I could write a review equivalent in length to War and Peace if I wished to list fully everything that I wanted to say about this game, so I'll give two versions - one brief and one a bit more in-depth, take your pick.

Here is the short version: Two Worlds EE is Skyrim with Oblivion graphics, there is as much to like about this game as there is to annoy, you need at least 3-4hrs in to start really enjoying it and remember, it's the first game from a small development team.
That's the short version. For those who want a bit more info, read on.

I went into this game, on the back of mixed reviews, not expecting a lot from it and was very pleasantly surprised by how much this game has going for it - yes, the graphics are a little outdated today, but it IS still a very pretty game overall  on max settings. Some of the scenery is beautifully breathtaking, but unfortunately pop-in and a fairly short draw distance does ruin it a little. And this is the story through the whole game. For every single thing I loved about this game, there was a downside - usually directly related to the thing I loved (such as the graphics example above). I loved the way the weapon/armour levelling system worked - downside, you never knew which items to keep (as there are literally hundreds  of both) and which to sell. I loved the diverse array of different environments on offer - downside, I spent 5-10mins exploring a new area and then half an hour putting stuff away to keep/save to sell in bulk, as you can build up your strength (helps with carrying), but once your inventory screen is full, you cannot carry anymore regardless of how much spare weight you can manage. I loved the large map, with virtually every environment you could think of in it - downside, there were parts where you wouldn't really have noticed if they weren't there (like empty stretches  of forest/grass/sand etc.) and mountain ranges devoid of everything and only 1 way up. I could go on and on, but you get the point.

The best features of this game, in my humble opinion, are: Huge range of weapons/armour/enemies; lots of diverse environments (even the dungeons don't seem 'samey' after you've been in 4); Skyrim-like short main questline with lots of 'mini' npc quests; every time I started to feel invincible I encountered a new enemy (they level up with you) who either gave me a damn good fight or made me run off with my tail between my legs (to come back later with better weapons); the ability to play the game as a medieval Rambo, a wizard, an archer (sniper) type or indeed ANY combination of the three at any one time! The best thing loved was the fact that even at 100hrs in, with 90% of the (large) map covered and almost finished all the quests, I was not only not bored and looking at what to play next, but was STILL finding new places and enemies! And it's the ONLY game I've played where walking through snow actually sounds like walking through snow!!! There is more, I could also list a lot more downsides, but basically just (re-) read the short version above and if that appeals to you then this game is definately worth giving it some play time. I'm looking forward to playing Two Worlds II soon.

reviewText:
A decent role-playing game for those who enjoy exploration and looting.

For some reason Two Worlds seemed to be mostly ignored by the gaming media. Perhaps because it did not have a very good marketing, hence it did not make a decent following before its release date. It was definitely not something it deserved. Two Worlds is an open-world RPG in a spirit of such games as Gothic and The Elder Scrolls. While it has many drawbacks, it certainly is a very enjoyable game at least for those players whom enjoy exploration and open-world games.

The game has a very disappointing storyline that is boring and forgettable. It only serves as a background for a player to do stuff. NPCs are quite shallow and without characters too. In addition, dialogues are horrible, not only writing is unsatisfying, but also dubbing is horrid. Although it sometimes is quite entertaining, it’s so bad that it’s good as one might say. Nonetheless, it’s definitely not a reason to play this game.

Two Worlds has some strong points though, and ultimately whether you will like the game or not depends how much you like exploration. If you love it as much as I do, then you will have a blast playing this game as it’s one of the better implemented exploration in RPGs. Not only locations are varied, but also there is no annoying level scaling of enemies or loot so prevalent in many modern RPGs and so annoyingly killing any challenge, joy and excitement out of discovering new lands. In Two Worlds you might encounter an enemy that is way above your level, however, if you are pertinacious enough, then you might kill them with use of some tricks anyway, but it might be a tough fight. Moreover, challenge is well worth it as loot that you might gain might make you more powerful. The game offers a huge gameworld and seems to be the first third person RPG that offers a decent horse riding and combat (Yes, you can fight while you are on a horse, unlike in Oblivion). Needless to say, that exploration is very satisfying, and so are combat encounters, although the combat itself is a bit too simple. However, in late game the player becomes too powerful and challenge perishes, unfortunately.

To summarize, Two Worlds is an enjoyable exploration RPG, however, with some weaknesses. I recommend it to everyone who like open world role-playing games for wandering around and experiencing new discoveries. Do not expect a good story or interesting NPCs though, as these aspects are lousy and will fail to meet your expectations whatever they are.

reviewText: I know this game is far from perfect, but I really enjoyed playing through it (in 2012). I didn't like it much when I started playing, but after I got the hang of it I started to really like it. I sure never thought I'd get over 100 hrs out of it (not too bad for $5 I paid for it a few years ago). Two Worlds is an open world RPG with big open areas. It's like the Gothic/Risen games in the sense that when you kill an enemy it's dead for good, and that the world is sprinkled with some really tough enemies you'll have to level up, gear up and come back later to defeat it. The combat is mostly mindless button mashing, but it does a good enough job with it. One cool thing about this game is that you can combine weapons and armor that are the same, so eventually that weapon you first had turns out to be really good after some time. The story is alright with terrible-ish voice acting, but the game is setup good enough that I didn't pay a lot of attention to it. The graphics aren't great, but are good (for the year it came out) although the framerate was kind of choppy. This game was relaxing for the most part. It was good for zoning out and killing tons of enemies. I will admit that the last 10 hours I ran through quickly just so I could beat it and be done with it. My rating 7/10.

After the dopey voice acting and cliche opening cutscene, my character was immediately murdered by a pack of wolves. After instantly respawning, I notice a glowing statue which regenerates my MP.

Then I see a grizzly bear.

I aggro'd the bear and then fired roughly 400 fireballs at him while running around and around this miraculous statue. When the bear finally succumbed to my barrage, I open the menu to find I had gained two levels. I used my newfound skill points to level up my fireball.

1 hour in and I am in love with this game already. 11/10

reviewText:
Regarded as one of the worst games ever created by many, I found this game to be highly enjoyable. The combat system has its faults, but the ability to become a mage-warrior had an appeal to me, and it was fun to play through the map in that role.

Pros:
Diverse landscapes including; snow, desert, meadows, mountains, hellish regions, beaches, forests.
Extremely intricate skill system.
Enormous map to explore, with many dungeons each of which different from the last.
Hundreds of different armor sets and weapon choices make customizing your character easy to suit your needs.
Hundreds of quests ranging from the classic fetch quest, to more detailed ones where your choices will play a role down the line.
Great combat system for warriors, mages, and archers alike.
Great variety of enemies to fight; humans, orcs, dragons, wyverns, raptors, wolves, and many more created just for the game that can be found in the bamboo forests, deserts, and beaches to name a few.

Cons:
Terrible voice acting.
Same battles over and over.
At a certain level combat just becomes too easy, especially with the Restore Health" spell that fully heals you at the cost of barely any Mana.

Overall

reviewText: Two Worlds is a game that has the right intentions and was headed in the right direction – it just had a few stumbling blocks en route. If you can get past some of those obstacles, you will find a very solid and entertaining RPG that will eat up a lot of hours.Two Worlds is worth a play, but only if you've exhausted the competition. And invested in ear plugs for when the characters start talking.To its credit, Two Worlds dares to be less conventional than Oblivion, but it's not nearly as polished in any regard. The unbalanced difficulty makes for a frustrating first few hours, and there's little incentive to return to the game after completing the main story line.It's a solid effort that may not bring a lot of ingenuity to the fantasy RPG genre, but still provides many hours of entertainment.Two Worlds succeeds at what it sets out to provide – a poor man’s Oblivion and a simple, unrestrictive introduction to role playing games. Overall 7/10.

reviewText:
I remember trying Two Worlds when it first came out years ago, and it was pretty horrible.  But I recently picked it up on sale and gave it a shot.  They really drop you in with absolutely no background, but you learn about the world very organically through conversations and quests.  These conversations are made through some of the most hilariously bad voiceovers I've heard, coupled with corny faux-fantasy writing.

But the style has kind of grown on me, and I am really enjoying the gameplay.  There's lots of loot, adventure, and exploration.  The character development is quite varied and interesting as well, with lots of playstyle options available.

If you can get past the initial low-quality shock, there's a really fun RPG in here.  Be sure to install the Nvidia legacy Physx pack to be able to run it, it is not included in the install:  http://www.nvidia.com/object/physx-9.12.1031-legacy-driver.html

reviewText:
In some ways, this game is better than Oblivion, the main competitor in the open-world fantasy genre, but there are quite a few issues and a real lack of polish that prevents the game from reaching its full potential.

The main gripe is combat. At later levels, the game becomes severely punishing. Now I don't mind difficulty, but this game likes  to suddenly throw overpowered monsters at you without warning. High level monster scale rediculously well. They will have a few times your health and do a couple times your damage. If you want to be able to take on high level challenges, you either have to grind out a lot of levels, which is done by killing monsters MMO style or through quests, or invest in the severely flawed magic system.

One can understand why the monster are so strong when one takes a look at what spells are available to the player. While finding the exact spell you want is nearly impossible, getting hands on any higher level spells makes your power level spike like crazy. I was able to get my hands on a reflect aura in the earth magic school. By abusing the magic system, I was able to get my reflect spell to reflect 70% of all damage. You heard that right, 70%. It seems the game will assume your use of of magic. By throwing out rediculous monsters, it forces you to be a sort of mage-warrior no matter what.

The leveling system in this game is actually more interesting than that of Oblivion's. There are a myriad of skills that can be learned, and the aforementioned magic system provides a bunch of really cool spells. Unfortunately, in terms of melee combat the game seems to favor two-handed weapons. The advantage of dual-wielding or using a sword and shield is the ability to parry attacks (done automatically). But one quickly realizes that isn't not worth it. It's far better to abuse the two-handed weapon's long range and simply physically avoid the ennemy blows, rather than nibling away at the enemy with the extremely short ranged one-handed weapons and relying on the dice to block strikes. It doesn't help that two-handed weapons all seem to deal double the damage of one handed weapons.

In a role-playing game, the player should never be forced to do something. All roles should be equally valid. Whether that be a mighty barbarian or a graceful duelist. But the game funnels you down a single path. With some more polish and a better balanced combat and magic system, I might have really enjoyed this game. But these gaping issues ruined it for me.

reviewText:
Good game, couple of flawsThis is a well made game. It's a bit linear as you have to do certain story parts to open up new areas. It does have replayability however, as you will pick one path and then try another path the second, third time. It's great to be a caster and attack a horde of orcs or a dragon with 8 conjured minions. I have primarily played a mage in this game up to a pretty high level. I did archer for quite some time as well, but it gets repetitive and is actually tougher than the mage. Thief is useless. The game doesn't force you into one of these archetypes, you are free to mix / match skills, but a hybrid in this game is weaker than a pure character. The game is good enough that I bother to write a review so that others will try this game.

Flaws:
1) Magic card system is weak. During combat, a caster is opening the magic window every few seconds to swap spell cards or enhancement cards. That said, the magic in this game is well thought out and looks great. I love my summoning demon bud!
2) Item collection becomes tedious and at higher levels you just give up on it. Early in the game you almost obsess over it. Later, you ignore all but the most intriguing items.
3) AI is weak. Mostly get bushwacked and charged. But, combat is interesting and looks great.
4) Sneaking is useless.

reviewText:
two worlds has become one of my favorite games ever, and noone is more surprised than me. first of all, I didn't start playing fantasy rpgs until a few years ago, they always looked too generic and boring, plus I really hated everything, and I mean everything, about the two worlds demo. but thankfully I gave it another shot and had a ton of fun playing it.

it's not a perfect game by any means, but also very far from the trainwreck a lot of reviews make it out to be. the graphics still hold up, the viewing distance is really amazing, you can see stuff in the distance from really far away (yet grass seems to grow under your feet, which is one of the very few complaints I have). the music's great too and the voice acting falls into the so-bad-it's-hilarious category. it was grating at first but became entertaining soon, the over the top usage of 'olde english', the protagonist's sarcastic remarks and taunts like 'say hello to death!' or 'they look like my in-laws'.

some of the mechanics are pretty interesting too: you can use a bunch of active skills during combat (after you learned them from trainers) and there's a jump back button, which is essential against bigger but slower enemies. there are horses, but I found them only useful as inventory extentions, just park them next to a teleport and you're good. riding on the road is actually fine, but as soon as you go off-road, it's hell. you can probably get the hang of it eventually, but with a generous amount of static teleports and your personal teleport stones you don't really need a mount to get around. sprinting would've been nice though, even if you run faster with your weapons put away.

speaking of weapons and gear, you can combine multiple copies of the same items to make them more powerful, which is great, and also makes inventory management easier. there's a crazy amount of loot in the game though, with a lot of variety in everything, so multiple trips to merchants will be necessary to grab and sell everything. I wouldn't have minded a third inventory screen, actually.

there's also magic and bows (no need to worry about arrows) and I'd say combat is good enough, you can mix things up, though it can get a bit hectic because aggroing an enemy usually mobilizes their friends as well. but most importantly (for me anyway), the game doesn't have respawning enemies (there's a ghost mechanic though that's explained in the game, but it's only troublesome in the beginning) nor level scaling, which can make for one-hit deaths early on if you run into something far above your level.

the alchemy system is pretty good too, you can make temporary and permanent potions and gems from almost everything, plants, monster drops, minerals, and they really make a difference. if you're into exploring and hoarding, you can become so powerful that almost everything will die in a few hits. this might be a problem for some, but you don't have to make potions, obviously, and you don't have to kill every wolf you run into for even more xp. that's what I did though: I can't remember the last game where I wanted to explore absolutely everything and where exploration was so relaxing even with literally thousands of enemies around. I'm not one for farming and grinding, but I killed them all (more than 10.000) while I was at it. I wouldn't say the game world is especially unique, though later on you'll run into some weird creatures and unsettling environments.

there are a lot of quests, some of them are pretty basic, some are more involved, and sometimes you have to make a decision, you can't complete everything (though it's possible to have max reputation with all the factions at the same time until you anger them). the main story is nothing to write home about, your sister's missing, go find her, oh, and save the world in the meantime, will you? the game shines in the sidequest department though. there are a few funny ones, some are touching, and they can have unforeseen consequences. you think you're done and did the right thing, but when you go back to the village or npc later, you'll find you actually made things worse. I loved these.

I could go on for days about the game but I'm sure these reviews have a character limit, so I'll stop before I get too much into it. long story short, if you're looking for an open-world fantasy rpg you probably haven't played, check this one out. if you want to do everything, it'll keep you busy for more than 100 hours (or you can just concentrate on questing and be done a lot faster).

reviewText:
Two Worlds is a tough game. The voice acting, horse-riding and combat at times, is all very ♥♥♥♥. Sometimes they have their moments but most of the time they struggke to reach average. But if you can somehow get past the inital crap then you find a gem.

Two Worlds is surprisingly deep, with a intriguing, large  and beautiful world.
The armor and weapons that you find start off looking rather dumb but soon you start finding very epic looking swords and axes, awesome spiked plate armor, damn i really liked one set of armor that i kept it for far longer then i should of, making the game harder then it should of been.
The crafting system in Two Worlds is very simple, just drag and drop, but i felt it went very well with the style of game and allowd even weaker waepons to stay strong with a little extra effort.
Alchemy is done well in the game as well, with you being able to craft many different potions of different effects out of many different ingrediants.
And the world, i really enjoyed just exploring the massive world and slaughtering the all bandits and helpless animals i came across.

I reccomend Two Worlds but know that many people will not be able to get over its flaws.
If realty pump only had a little extra funding or more time or whatever, they could of made a truely epic game.

reviewText: I've been playing Two Worlds for the better part of 40 hours and I am loving it!  It's not Skyrim, DragonAge, or The Witcher, but I'm finding it to be a deeply interesting and fun RPG to play.  It has a well developed world full of warring factions, magic, skills, and horse back riding.  I actually like the horse back riding better in Two Worlds than in Skyrim (IMHO).  The questing in my mind is what is the most fun in this game.  Two Worlds is loaded with cities, caves, dungeons, and quests to complete.  This is not an expensive game and I've seen it goes as low as 1.49.  This game has issues and some very quirky dialogue, but I still recommend it.  I could have finished the main quest 15 hours ago, but I'm having too much fun with the side quests.  I've seen a lot of bad reviews for this game and I can understand some of the complaints, but I find this game so much fun and the quirks and bugs just simply don't bother me.  Lovely weather" said the hero as he stormed through the rain shower that just popped up.  Love It!"

reviewText:
A great game, very underrated. In many respects similar to an Elder Scrolls game with the same freedom of movement, collecting alchemy ingredients, running around doing quests, and the same sense towards the end of the game that you can destroy everything with ease.

Enemies tend to be in either groups of average strength or single or pairs of overwhelming strong enemies. They have to be managed differently, and archery is actually very usefull especialy when facing large number of archers who can disarm you and do decent levels of damage.

The first 30 minutes of the game is a grind but get past that and the game becomes very enjoyable.

One of the really enjoyable things about the game is that the guards of towns are no stronger than they should be. So if you are able to take down a cyclops or slay a dragon you don't get the sillyness of guards being able to bash you up. In fact if you want you can rampage through the world slaying everyone and reserecting people afterwards. It's slightly over the top but it really adds to the enjoyment.

reviewText:
I'll probably complete this review when I'll complete it, but since I noticed it's on sale at 90% off (0.99€ here) and I just started playing it, I just wanted to give it my thumbs up with a quick review after about 23 hours of game time.

I was very dubious if to waste my time on this since the mixed reviews, but I'm happy that I didn't listen.

You're not always ready for some game that will take your life away for months or years to come, so if you still want to play a relatively modern and open-world RPG without the need to take weeks to learn how things work and how to craft stuff, this might just be the game for you.

There's plenty of items in this game, and you can choose your own path into anything (warrior, mage and so on) upgrade after upgrade, to shape your character into what you want without having to decide that at the start of the game, but without becoming too complicated. Sure, the game don't tell you basically anything about how anything works, but you can always read the pdf manual that Steam gives you and find all the details there, but anyway, after just 1.5 hours I already was going through the menus without problems and without ever reading the manual.
There's stuff you'll learn with practice or by trial and error, but if you don't want to read that pdf you can consider it like an adventure in the adventure :)
One very useful thing that the game don't tell you (or I didn't notice) is that you can merge 2 identical items into a better one by just drag and dropping one onto the other one, while in your inventory. That way you can improve your current equipment for free, without the need to buy a better one.

Now I just hope I won't hit that quest bug that another user experienced, that seem to happen because some side-quests can break the main quest if done before it, but I'm trying to not let the main quest behind too much and I hope that'll be enough.

reviewText:
TLDR: Two Worlds is The Room of RPGs. It's somehow both bad and fun at the same time.

Lets get this out of the way: this is a trashy Eastern European RPG. The generic plot is written in bad ye olde englishe and spoken by the worst non-native speakers this side of House of the Dead. It will actively try to disuade you from paying attention to the plot, and yet IT WON'T SHUT UP. Hoods breath, does this game have diarrhea of the mouth.

And yet, it's really enjoyable for the cheap RPG it is. Once you realize that all weapons attack at the same speed and dodging instantly makes you immune to damage, you can cheese the game like a boss. Oh, and when you die, you just respawn at the nearest health shrine, no xp loss or anything. Still not as great as other European RPGs like Gothic or Risen, but it's not the hellspawn that it has the reputation for. Then again, I really enjoy terrible movies, so I guess I just have trashy taste.

reviewText:
The first hour of playing this game leaves you with a poor sensation of what it is. When you have gone beyond that point, it's actually really enjoyable.

The old-fashioned graphics, the dozens of exploits and odd characters gives the game a nice atmosphere.
The crafting and magic aspect is great once you get into it.
You can freely choose how the story will unfold and often you get the choice to continue helping certain NPC's or kill/betray them to help others instead.
The item and loot system is decent, but the ability to stack armor and weapons to improve the gear and save space is really brilliant.


The fights can be somewhat clunky at times with certain skills/weapon combinations, although it can easily be avoided.
The horse-mechanics are annoying, but they have other uses besides transportation.
Quest can sometimes be rather vague in describtion, but compared to how easy they usually are these days, it can be a nice change of pace for some.

*Watch out for the random spider spawns in Cathalon, they are terrifying.

reviewText: I have played this game years ago. It was one of, if not THE first solid RPG experience I've had. I loved it from the first day, and to this day, I still love it. The world is immersive, and MASSIVE, you can never say you've explored it all. I remember challenging myself to explore EVERY SINGLE dungeon in the world, and I yet didn't finish that. Unfortunately, I lost the game CD, but now that I bought it again on Steam, it's time to play! Yes, the story, the dialogue may be cheesy, you might encounter funny bugs, although I know they've fixed most of them, but there are so many things that you can see and do that you can easily cast aside all the negative and just enjoy it. Now excuse me, I have quests to do, dungeons to explore and monsters to slay! I totally recommend this game to anyone willing to have fun!

reviewText:
This game is an underrated gem, I recommend it highly to any fan of open-world RPGs. It's biggest hurdle is just its first impression. The character creation is a joke, the cut-scenes & voice-acting are hammy, the controls and menu navigation a bit unintuitive, initially.

However, give this game an hour or two to grow on you, and you will find a vastly underrated, very free, open-world fantasy RPG that will give you hundreds of hours of enjoyment. The loot is vast and randomly generated (and items are stackable, which means looting never gets entirely old); the levelling is well-paced and addictive; the scope of abilities interesting to experiment with (archery, traps, magic, various combat techniques, etc.)  The alchemy/crystal system is very interesting as well, though you might want to download a strategy guide to get the most out of it.

Combat and enemy AI are weak and relatively easy to exploit, but that didn't bother me much -- I just view the game as more of a Diablo-esque, loot-driven kind of experience, vs. a game built around challenging/nuanced combat. And although the story and voice-acting initially seem awful, the cheesiness of it becomes a part of the charm, and the protagonist is often actually very funny. He becomes strangely good company as you go roaming the world by yourself.

Visually, the game holds up exceptionally well, if you have a good graphics card. I don't know if the graphics were revamped for the epic edition, but at times the game looks on a par with a high-end Skyrim, and the world can be quite beautiful. There is also a ton of detail in the armor, weapons, etc. I've also had no problems with bugs/crashes or anything like that, with the Epic Edition.

Also a plus: the world is absolutely *huge*. I am certain it is much bigger than any recent Bethesda games by far, and the environments are quite varied once you get out a bit.

In short, this is a game that got -- to my mind -- unfairly passed over when it was released. It does have its quirks and doesn't make a great first impression when you start up, but I can honestly say I've had as much fun with this game as any other open-world RPG you can name, and like it as well -- if not better -- than Skyrim. They're just different. At anything <$20 -- let alone the 2.99 or so you often see it for -- it is an absolute steal.

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Two Worlds doesn't have the amount of exploration and interesting content as the Elder Scrolls: Oblivion does, but it certainly has its own unique charm. Two Worlds captures that old RPG feel that seems lost in the games of our current generation, it felt very akin to playing the original Ever Quest. From the start of multiplayer mode, you'll be getting your ♥♥♥♥ handed to you on a silver platter over and over and over again, and the enemies will promptly give you more beatings.

There's challenge to be had here, but it doesn't add much to the genre overall. I've heard that through the later levels you have a lot more freedom to customize your character, but I didn't see much through the miniscule time that I played. It was just basic kill X target or gather X item, not much innovation. The lower level multiplayer enviroments don't look very interesting, and I imagine it would be a bore to trudge through without a friend by your side.

Within the multiplayer component, the quest rewards were very underwhelming. In the map that I played, all I gained from completing them was gold, gold, and more gold. Where are the unique items, you might ask? They're sold by NPCs, or sometimes found on corpses, or within treasure chests.

If you bore easily, this isn't the game for you. I wouldn't recommend playing multiplayer without a friend, my friend and I only saw five other people playing at the same time. I can't speak for the singleplayer content as I haven't played it, but I imagine it's more or less the same. The story and voice acting are also terrible, so I wouldn't purchase the game if you're looking for that.

You should also know that there are some nasty bugs that come along with this game, after several hours of playing multiplayer, I abruptly crashed and lost all of my progress. So be wary of the multiplayer aspect of the game, you could unexpectedly lose all of your progress, and there is no fix for this that I know of.



tl;dr

Two Worlds brings back the old school feel, but it doesn't measure up to other games released in its time period. If you're looking for a great RPG experience, I'd recommend Oblivion or Dragon Age: Origins.

4/10. It's an average and bland game, but that's part of its charm.

reviewText: Ok, I just bought the game on steam for $1 as the epic edition (on sake at 80%) apparently after having been patched to hell and back and...you know what? It's not horrible. I get that that it's long past the redemption area now but it's actually quite playable and compared to the 360 version, there is no frame-rate issue...and I'm playing this on an Ideapad with integrated graphics. Yes combat is a bit loose and awkward but it is doable and the story and dialogue aren't that bad. Exploration is huge and vast. Respawning is a nice change of pace from some RPGs I've played. Is it Oblivion or better than? No. Is it now a competent RPG on its own? Yes, actually. I paid a buck and...I got a lot more than my money's worth.

reviewText: I played Two Worlds a lot in 2010 on the disc version of this, amassing around 150 hours in it. The acting is rubbish to be quite honest, and the story isn't that exciting(when you finish it, the game simply ends - I didn't actually feel inspired to finish it until I was nearly done with the sidequests). The main reason I had such a long playtime for it was because of the weapon upgrade system which had me running around randomly searching for weapons to combine with what I already owned(and usually find something better), the sidequests which sometimes had an interesting bit of backstory to them and the NPCs(in cities especially) who were remarkably fun to kill or scare with different types of spells(Guards will instakill you at first though).\n\nTwo Worlds is also still fairly nice looking for the age it is - don't expect groundbreaking graphics, but the green environments especially still look quite nice.

reviewText:
Some people seem to genuinely enjoy this game.  That caught me off-guard.

In 2007, I'd heard all the hype about this being the next great RPG.  Just coming off Oblivion (which I'd played obsessively), I was so excited for Two Worlds!

Well, I played it about 30 minutes, was horrendously disappointed, laughed at it a bit, and gave up.  It's very pretty.  That's about all I have to say about it.

Recently, seeing all the positive (??) reviews for the game, I grabbed it for $2.  Well, I wish I had my money back.  I gave it another try.  If there is redeeming value in this game, I can't find it.  The combat is awful, it's buggy, the dialog is laughable...

Two Worlds II, on the other hand, is actually underrated.  It's a lot of fun.  That's another reason I gave this game a second shot.  The sequel is so much fun, despite not exactly being brilliant, so maybe I missed something in the original?

Well, again, if I'm missing something, I can't find it.  I have a pretty high tolerance for crappy RPGs, but I can't tolerate this one.

reviewText:
Back in 2006, Elder Scrolls: Oblivion was the most popular open-world RPG, but a year later, Two Worlds was released, and the RPG fans wonder how much batter it would be.

Well, 8 years have passed and Two Worlds remains forever in Oblivion’s shadow. Above all negative towers this Reality Pump release, the story-line gets the worst part. Not-so-epic, and somehow basic, we take the role of a traveller searching for his sister who is mysteriously kidnaped. After being approached by a strange man who leads us to the main quest, we start our journey only to realise the side-quests are actually more interesting. Despise all the shortness, the main-quest encourages the player to explorer the kingdom, complete site-quests, gain reputation among the several available factions, choose a side among the war against the orcs, and discover new areas.
Much like Gothic series, this action RPG gives you the freedom to explore the world as you want, with an amazing combat system that puts you to the test by fighting bandits, goblins, wild animals, Cyclops, and many other creatures we are used to encounter in this genres. Getting yourself in the wrong side of the map might lead you to difficult enemies, but with great rewards worth the trouble.
Two Worlds offers a simple and interesting system where the player can create new items by cooking all sort of organic and magic objects. Mixing up till 5, the result may be different each time you tweak with the items, but you get to keep all the recipes for future use. New potions with a lot of different results are the most common, this will certainly make the game a lot easier, since harvesting items can be done pretty much everywhere. You can’t craft new weapons, but you can upgrade them, and that’s good enough. There’s plenty to choose from the vast variety of armour-sets, swords, staffs, and many more powerful objects to kill all those evil Golems!
The player also relies on magic, and for that the levelling up is great, choose among the 5 elements, and advance your combat skills and how well you manoeuvre your weapons.
Although the gameplay is flawless and the graphics try to keep with it, the major problem falls upon the text-dialogue. NPC are just repetitive, in both appearance and dialogues, and that’s really a shame, because some actually tell you interesting things about the world of Two Worlds. It’s a big map, but very repetitive, even with snow, desert and deep forests, the game lacks on dungeons with only a handful of them to complete and loot. Small huts and villages with hidden secrets might be your salvation after a long walk throughout the world.

With great emphasis on side-quests, your journey won’t be a waste of time, and in time you may learn to enjoy it.
One of those games where you love it or hate it. Can’t go medium with this one, it’s made for RPG fans. Unless you are one, stay way.
Could be batter, but could be a lot worst considering all things! 6/10.

reviewText:
My experience with Two Worlds is that it is COMPLETE, unplayable feces. I don't know what it is about my computer, but this game refuses to play on it under any circumstances. I believe I got it to work once, right after I got it, and when I got the game, the controls were absolutely atrocious and unintuitive on the xbox 360 gamepad.

Now though, I can't even get this game to run without crashing to desktop with a 'Two Worlds is not responding' message, and I know what the common issues with this game are, I've tried all of the 1 fix I've ever seen for this game crashing, which is installing the proper nvidia Physx legacy driver. I've done that exact thing, installing and uninstalling the drivers multiple times, verifying game caches, uninstalling and reinstalling the game, running a command line parameter that allows me to finally launch the game in a tiny window only for it to crash while loading. This game doesn't know how to function. The programmers must have been complete idiots when they made this.

The only positive thing to come away from this game with is that at least the developers learned from this and made Two Worlds II a much more competent, smoother, and overall better experience. If you wanna check out Two Worlds, don't bother, get the sequel.

----------
Edit:

Alright. I finally got this thing to work, and here was the problem, files in OTHER GAMES I OWNED were keeping this game from running. I have no clue how ANYONE can fail at programming a game so hard that having another file in another location on your computer for another game keeps this other, ENTIRELY DIFFERENT GAME from FUNCTIONING. The solution, to people who had the same problem as me is, check your games for lgvid.ax files and delete them. These files are most common in Looking Glass's Dark Engine games (System Shock 2, Thief Gold, and Thief 2: The Metal Age are the most likely culprits). While I could also use that as an opportunity to lay the blame on those games, the fact of the matter is, I have over 200 games in my library and not ONE besides this game ceased to function just because of a file it shouldn't even be referencing that exists in my other games.

That said, if you can fix it and get it working, Two Worlds is worth trying. Getting past the technical issues, I have been playing the game quite regularly in the past week or so, putting in over 20 hours already, and most of that was just me exploring, killing monsters and bandits and groms and animals, then looting, equipping, improving, and selling their stuff without doing any quests. So I'd say it makes for a fairly enjoyable sandbox Action-RPG that I would recommend, but again, ONLY if you have no issues getting it to run. The technical issues should be a big red flag if you plan on getting this game at anything other than a considerable discount.

reviewText: Two Worlds is an exciting and story-rich RPG. You play as a mercenary who will do anything to save his sister, Kira. There are many enemies you must face: blood-thirsty orcs, golems, ogers, dragons, necromancers, you name it. I'm just going to say it straight-forward. This game is hard. When you first start out, you are extremely weak; you struggle to slay a couple bandits without using a health potion or spell. As you progress things only become harder. You may be able to slay 12 bandits with your mighty greatsword with no problem at all. But how will you fare against an oger? Or 5 necromancers? It is satisfying, being able to kill something you once struggled to even hit. But know that there will always be an enemy that will utterly destroy you. When you die, you respawn at the last shrine you visited (there are A LOT of shrines around the world). You don't have to go back to your last save or anything like that. Which can be both good and bad. The game play is great, the graphics are good enough to keep your immersion, and the voice acting is mediocre at best. There are flaws, but there is a lot of fun gameplay here. Unfortunately, after you complete the game, there's virtually no replay value. I haven't picked it up since I beat it. So, if you're looking for a game you can beat multiple times consecutively, then this isn't the game for you. I had fun playing it, and I do recommend it if you're looking for a good open world RPG.\n8/10

reviewText:
Not the greatest game, but a damn fine buy at $1.49.

I bought this & like many before me, immediately experienced crashing. after checking the forum I quickly found a link to a legacy driver that fixed the issue. I had issues getting my gamepad to work with the game, but conquered that battle. And even after getting the gamepad to work, the game (especially the combat) handles like a monster truck with no power steering. Now don't get me wrong even after all the issues above & the occasional crash (after 20+ I experienced: 1 during gameplay & 1 lock up during exiting the game) this game is pretty friggen good.

Combat is a bit clunky. I wish it was as polished as Amalur's, but I wasn't expecting a whole hell of a lot coming into this one. The best I can say for combat is it's passable.

Storyline is above average. Not too cliche.

Graphics are not horrible for a 2009 release.

Audio is pretty damn good. I found my self impressed with the wildlife sounds Top Ware bothered to add.

Two Worlds WILL fight with you. Knowing that, would I recommend it at full price? Probably not, there are better games out there more deserving of the $9.99. I would say grab this fast, if it's on sale & you enjoy 3rd person, open world RPGs..... Oh & if you have the patience.

reviewText: Okay, before looking at the time I have spent sofar on this game for PC, please realize I have it for 360 as well, and beat it with about 200 hours or so and all the achievements. This game is amazing, hands down. While the graphics and voice acting is not the best to todays standards, it is still pretty good. The story line is like a 7/10 for me, but the side quests are very good. NOTHING respawns in this game, so it is possible to kill everything in the game and be stuck with nothing to do. I do love the part of the map where the volcanos are and all that, as it was done very nice. The mobs are fantastic and unique as well, such as the Lava Dragon. It might start out hard in certain areas, but once you get to about level 45 or so, you can pretty much 1 hit everything except the boss and mobs in the hell area. 10/10 game for me. I do not like the second game much though...

reviewText:
One of the classics from our childhood. Put in context this game offered a lot of land to travel, side quests, freedom of movement and consequences for the deccisions you take. The main cons are the scarce explanations about how everything works and the DRM system, which was bad even for those years.

After this game they came great titles in the genere like Oblivion, Skyrim, The Witcher II, etc. So this one is nowadays suits best for nostalgic gamers and collectors.

Of course, if you get it at a reasonable price and you want to be patient and put some time into the game it's probably a title that will surprise you despite the first impression.

reviewText:
Underneath this somewhat unpolished game, marred by huge expectations (pre-release hype expected this game to be the next Oblvion open-world game), and a horrible buggy release, lies an enjoyable, often unique open-world RPG game, a game that I can recommend to open-minded gamers.

It's amazing I can say that because on release, when I first got the Xbox 360 version, it looked like I had made a mistake. Tons of framerate issues, game-breaking bugs, and moreover a very unimpressive intro and beginner newbie area. The game eventually got patched, and I enjoyed it enough to later buy the PC version, and for my friends and I, Two Worlds 1 has become a guilty pleasure. I actually bought this twice on the PC, directly from publisher and later via Steam, so my hours don't reflect all of my accumulated playing time.

I have to stress, though, that you have to weather the horrible beginning of the game. The game cinematic intro is uninspiring, then it drops you into a forest area, eventually giving you a barebones tutorial that doesn't show you the cool features of the game. On top of that, you have to make your way to your first town which sports some of the worst voice acting I've heard heard in a game. Fortunately, the voice acting improves a bit as you get further into the game, however the dialogue is still pretty bad, but you get used to it.

On your way to the town, you may get mauled by wolves, which travel in packs, which until you learn the agro system of the game, you may die repeatedly.  So often, gamers will just quit at this point, several hours into the game, which is a shame, and I believe why most people didn't give this game a fair shake.  Lots to learn -- how to use the magic system, how to collect ingredients, how to handle night time creatures in the game (you won't be able to kill them initially so run away from them), etc.

I really liked the weapon-combining system which I wish more games would implement.  You can combine similar weapons to upgrade your main weapon, so alleviates inventory issues, just keep combing that generic sword over and over. It also solves the moan-and-groan of finding junk loot, because in this game, you can make an uber weapon out of crappy weapons. Of course, eventually you'll want to combine higher-level weapons, but it's a great way to lessen inventory issues.

I also loved the co-op feature, able to the play the entire game again with a friend. Not sure if you can still do this, though, because I don't remember if it needed access to original Two Worlds servers.

Character models may look a bit dated, but the world still looks pretty good, and it has a lot of variety. Lots of side-quest and secrets to explore and enough variety to replay the game with different classes, which is also a strength, Classes aren't set in stone, but you can develop your character however way you want. Some people have issues with the mounting system, getting aggravated with the horse mount, but I found the PC version is far improved over the 360 version.

Two Worlds 2, the sequel,  is by far, a more polished game, but TW1 sports a larger world, and doesn't have the weapon combining feature. If you can do some reading of the game mechanics, and not give up right away, you may find yourself enjoying this game.

Personal terms: worth purchase (i got on sale with 80% of discount)
Impartial traditional terms: 5/10
Personal sentimental judgment (Just for the record): 7/10

I like this game, a lot. To me is a great game, really got me absorbed, and I probably will play a hundred more hours. This game need to be remembered with some honors. But you can't take my personal judgment as guarantee you gone like. To me is a great game, as i said.

There is a lot issues in this game, but a lot of good thing too.
Good characteristics:
*Real Open World
*Nonlinear campaign progress.
*Smooth loot and inventory system.
*Interesting lore
*Extremely big variety of enemies
*Hundreds types of armor and weapons
*Very deep and easy magic system

Bad characteristics:
*Horrible voice acting
*You won't feel connected to the game
*The way the quest are display on your map can be confused.
*Combat can be boring.
*Lack of lapidation.
*Open areas can be empty, because the enemies don't respawn.
*There is no books or anything like to read in the game, what would make the story and mythology more complete and interesting to understand.
*No crafting system.

I didn't understand why but the autosave system has a facility to put you into a death loop, and the game only keep a history of three autosaves, what is a flaw in a Open World game. Once two of my three autosave got into a death loop and I almost lose all my campaign progress. But fortunately you can manually create an unlimited number of manual saves.

Personally this game really is a hidden preciosity, for some RPG fan only, and I can't recommend to everybody. If you're not a great RPG fan will be some kinda difficult to you like this particular game. If you are a casual is almost certain you'll not gonna like it. Is a good RPG, with some interesting lore, but has also to many problems. Two Words also doesn't have a good replayability, everyone who beat the game is almost certain that he wil never play this game again. Is extremely inferior compared to others RPG Open World in the time was release, but in my personal experience this franchise became a remarkable experience in one of my favorite types of games. What I can say is: 5/10. Is just a normal game, have just enough to be average, nothing realy attractive, is just a game that dont sucks (considering the PC version only, stay away from the console version). reviewText:
Why can't my horse keep a straight line? Why won't it turn where I want to go? Why can't I cast a spell on a moving horse? How do the skill shortcuts work? Why can't I reassign them? Why only 3 spells at a time? Why this botched and weird alchemy system? Why did I keep playing? So many questions, a couple of laughs, and a good amount of frustration later I did actually finish this game, in a most shameful binge. That's one thing this game has over Skyrim/Oblivion I suppose... I bothered to finish it. Towards the end I skipped most quests and hated the ones I had to do and I am very glad I am finished with this game.

Once you figure it out (and you will have to, and make allowances for bugs and glitchiness, etc), this game opens up and is pleasant enough to play despite the annoyingly slow animations, dumb plot and characters, general uninspiredness, useless and bugged and bizarre skills, and general laughability. It reminds me a lot of Dungeon Siege if it was mixed with Morrowind and made in eastern Europe, which I guess is why it spoke to me more than Skyrim/Oblivion did. Permanent +stat potions make alchemy necessary and briefly interesting as you seek new ingredients and wonder how/if they'll work. If this game had been allowed to gestate another 6 to 8 months it would've been pretty good, possibly better than the games it was competing with. As it stands, it's a large mostly empty world filled with nothing but annoying chained fetchquests, and it will give you the sense it's a rush job.

The little teleport stones (as in Divine Divinity) are brilliant and make up for some of the annoyances of travel - more games need that or at least Mark/Recall ability. Swimming is ridiculously bad and that they made it skillbased was a really bad choice - there are some major design issues with this game. It only crashed once when I played it, and there were no game-breaking bugs, but some of the quests are a little wonky. There is almost no replay value here, but on sale it should cost less than 2 bucks, which is roughly a fair price for the enjoyment you should be able to eke out of it. I don't think I'll return for Game 2, but I had my fun and laughed pretty hard at some of the oddities of this game. +1 for Taint Shoots.

(If you really want to have a laugh after you finish this, check out youtube user 'ProJared's' review, in which he, the babylike pro, admits to having problems playing an incredibly simple and generally unchallenging game and cheating to defeat it because it's unfair. This game was many things as well as being poorly designed, but only blatantly unfair at the very end.)

reviewText: I've only really started playing this game today, and I have to say, for it being quite an old game it is still fun to play, and worth a try if you are looking for a rpg to play. I really like the alchemy system, you have 4 slots I believe if i can remember, and you get ingredients from plants or wildlife that give you buffs. The skill system makes sense and I honestly have no problem with it, it has a sense of progression. For instance you have to be a certain level before you can put more points into a skill. This way you don't find yourself leveling one skill the entire time. I also like the fact that there is reputation with the factions in the game. It runs on a scale of 1-10, 1 being not important and 10 being very important. The more quests you do for a faction the more rep you gain. The questing is fun and the voice acting isn't really all that bad, It's better than reading quests (Morrowind). At the beginning it is sort of rough, but once you can get some gear from crushing some Grom skulls you'll be fine :)
