reviewText:
Played this game for years already, but decided to write a review now to correct some wrong statements in some of the negative reviews.

The game runs fine with Win. 8.1!!! You can see my Steam playtime, most of it was created with Win 8.1. And I never had a single crash. There IS a problem starting the game at first, but this can easily be fixed by searching the forum and downloading the correct drivers.

Two Worlds is several years old, so of course you can't expect graphics of 2015. But for its age, it looks quite good imo. You can customize your hero to some point, so if he looks like a goblin, it's not the fault of the game...

The combat and general controls: I have neither the time nor the patience to struggle with complex controls, so if I enjoy a game (and I DO enjoy Two Worlds a lot) you can be sure it's not too hard to handle. Movement, inventory, map and stuff are standard. You need your LM for your weapon and your RM for special attacks and magic. With your mousewheel you can easily toggle between the desired abilites. It's really not THAT hard. For starters there's even a manual in your Steam library.

It's a large world with about 170 quests in total and the possibility to explore everything, so you'll be busy for a while. There are no classes, you can develop your character as you wish and choose your abilites from close and ranged combat, traps, stealth and 5 different magic schools. There's a big amount of weapons and armor as well as a lot of different enemies.

Furthermore you have alchemy, lockpicking and horses (and in contrast to what some people say riding is pretty easy).

All in all I really enjoy this game again and again. The only complaint I have is the activation limit (when your activations are gone, you have to contact support to reset them), but the developers think of removing it. If they do, you should give it a try.

reviewText:
First of all, this isn't really for those who haven't played the good Open-World RPGs like Skyrim and Oblivion.

It has its own charm though. It's a fun open world RPG in a campy kind of way. The dialogue is fairly poorly acted and written, but with a fun, unique olden charm. There's no level cap, so the character keeps growing as you play, and once you cap skills you can just branch out.

The graphics are slighty under the baseline set by pre-mod Elder Scrolls, but it still works.

The weapon and armor improvement system is pretty unique and a lot of fun to work with too.

Combat takes a bit to get used to since it can be unforgiving, and stealth doesn't work too well, but it's still a fair deal of fun once you get going.

At $10 this campy game is a steal.

reviewText: This game is extremely clumsy, a bit buggy, but it definitely has charm. The dialog is obnoxiously stiff, but it has character. The combat and physics are kinda wonky, but it means you never know quite what's going to happen. The environment is decent, for a game of this age, but the main plot is pretty boring. The hero is so damn macho. All in all, enjoyable for a few dollars.

reviewText:
It's so flawed and yet I derived a sense of enjoyment from this game. The unlimited potential for your character to evolve into a god is pretty fun, with a huge variety of armour and weapons. The voice acting is hilariously bad, the animations are rough and it can take a lot of trial and error to get the combat right but it's oddly charming. The world map is fairly large for it's time and all the frame rate issues from the console version have been ironed out. If you're looking for a huge, camp and Gothic-esque RPG this is perhaps for you.

This is definitely a love it or hate it kind of game, however if you're curious I cannot stress enough that it is best to buy this on a sale (it is fairly old now) and you -need- the old Nvidia physx legacy drivers, otherwise this game won't launch.

Played on Windows 7/GTX 780

reviewText:
I really would recommend this game, I have invested about 25 hours in total into this game and I picked this up at 69p on a weekly sale. I'll list the pros and cons;
Pros  It has a large world to explore and there is fast travel for those who wish to use it.
There are a lot of quests and sidequests.
A system of combining identical equipment you find to improve it, this makes it hard to choose what to use i.e. should i use this really good sword or keep my old one and keep improving since it's more common?
There are a lot of different weapons and equipment to find/loot.
Things like archery and chemistry are actually things you need to improve and learn rather than just knowing straight away.
Each city has noticeable differences in culture which I really liked.
Cities are quite large, compared to Skyrim where the cities are more like towns this actually does have large cities, it comes at a price of sacrificing the size of indoors however.  I am not saying it's better than Skyrim
Cons  It has some of the worst voice acting I've ever seen in a game, get used to hearing mayhaps, aye, and perchance just thrown into conversation with a slow talking drone.
When an enemy is dead, they're dead, any random bandit encounters won't happen again once you kill them. Nothing respawns.
It is very challenging to start, it starts you off with very poor equipment and launches you straight into what seems like at the time level 1000 enemies, you can still beat them it just requires a lot of determination.
The main story is very boring so if you like story based games, probably want to avoid this.
It seems a bit expensive given the experience playing it, don't get me wrong I loved playing it but that is mainly due to me buying it at 69p.
Money pretty much has no value, countless times I would buy a 5000 gold sword and be broke and jump straight back up to 5000 within a few minutes just from selling loot and finding gold, this is good in some ways but not very challenging.

There are many more things to say about this game but I cannot think of more at the minute. If i was to offer a comparison as to what Two Worlds is like then I would say it's something like what Oblivion would have been like if Bethesda would've had a fraction of it's budget.

reviewText: I've only really started playing this game today, and I have to say, for it being quite an old game it is still fun to play, and worth a try if you are looking for a rpg to play. I really like the alchemy system, you have 4 slots I believe if i can remember, and you get ingredients from plants or wildlife that give you buffs. The skill system makes sense and I honestly have no problem with it, it has a sense of progression. For instance you have to be a certain level before you can put more points into a skill. This way you don't find yourself leveling one skill the entire time. I also like the fact that there is reputation with the factions in the game. It runs on a scale of 1-10, 1 being not important and 10 being very important. The more quests you do for a faction the more rep you gain. The questing is fun and the voice acting isn't really all that bad, It's better than reading quests (Morrowind). At the beginning it is sort of rough, but once you can get some gear from crushing some Grom skulls you'll be fine :)

reviewText:
Recommendation: Play the game with the sound turned off, or at least the voice acting. If you can manage, maybe even turn off subtitles, too.

This game has a lot going for it, but it's the small things that kill it, and there are so many of them. The voice acting and writing are horrible. The horse riding is a janky pile of garbage. I think the horse only has 5 frames of animation, and it has a (somewhat deficient) mind of its own, often deciding to veer in the opposite direction you indicated. The graphics are pretty bad. I'm all for taking into account the age of the game, but there are plenty of games this old that don't look this bad. It's surprising, because some of the assets look pretty good, while others look terrible. It's like they just lumped together a bunch of assets they had sitting around. The quests are also confusing and not very descriptive. I had to look up several of them in online guides.

There are plenty more, but I stopped playing mostly because of those. It was just, plain silly. Pity, because I actually enjoyed a lot about this game. I still need to try TW2 to see if it's any better.

reviewText:
Probably the best game on Steam. No, I'm serious.

This game is simply amazing. It's one of the best I've ever have played.

To start off the story is astounding. Never have I played a game with such a massively in depth and rememberable tale such as this. You start off in the immensely fascinating world of Thalmont. The hero is on a quest to discover the mysteries of an ancient orcish curse left behind by the late Azrael who is the son of the executioner of Hell and a mortal woman. The hero is traveling with his sister, Kira, who holds the key to the knowledge about resurrecting Azrael. Gandohar, a powerful wizard that seeks to harness the power of Azrael for himself learns of this and then sets out to kidnap Kira.

Throughout the game the hero is trying to find where the scoundrel Gandohar has taken his sister. Along the way he is forced to work with Gandohar as well as Reist Tungard, a shadow of a man who turns out to be a demon sent from hell. The hero battles his way through countless obsticles to try to save his sister. At the very end he is forced to make a choice that will inpact the destiny of the entire world.

As for the game itself it's an amazing action RPG that rivals games like Skyrim and Dark Souls. The combat is extremely well balanced and always put you on the edge of your seat.

The voice acting is phenomenal and makes you feel as though you are really in a dark medieval fantasy world. Almost every character has a unique voice actor and a interesting character model to go along with it.

You can also customize your character much like the elder scrolls games. I find the customization to be better than the default elder scrolls process. You can increase every little detail from the height of the character to the arm legth and even small things such as the eye size. I personally made my character look like Steve Stifler from the American Pie movies.

Overall I'd give this game a 11/10. It is truly one of the best games of this century. If you haven't played it then BUY IT NOW. It's only $0.99 which is a steal for such an amazing game.

reviewText: For its price point the game is decent but honestly it's pretty terrible overall. Enemies come in packs of 3-6 which is difficult/tedious to defeat early on, so your best strategy is to stand by a revive shrine and fight with rapidly regenerating health. Later on you're broken because alchemy is overpowered in that it lets you make permanent stat potions from easily obtainable materials. That and you can stack gems on a weapon and make its damage obscene.\n\nThe real problem is the lack of quest markers. You know how you've probably played a game and thought wow it's really lame this marker leads me right to the objective" Well
date: if you want to see why developers do that
recommended: try this game!!!!!! While there are quest markers most of them are to the person giving the quest and you get to wander around most of the time lost. Most of the directions are vague like "near" or "east of" and then not really either.\n\nThere's also really draconic DRM too which apparently only allows three installs. The game's playable I guess... I mean it held my attention longer than Morrowind in this day and age
hoursPlayed: but really it's quite poor quality unfortunately."

reviewText:
One could say that for every two things  Two Worlds  did right, there's one thing it did wrong.
In my opinion, it still deserves a positive rating (especially since you can now get it for free on DLH.net), but let's talk about some of the aspects.


The in-game world is beautiful; full of interesting locations to visit and a variety of things to do.
There is also a simple (simple" doesn't equal "bad"
recommended: so you can choose your play style: an elemental wizard
voteText: a warrior
helpfulPercent: an archer or even sort of a stealthy "bandit"... or a mix of them all
votesHelpful: just like it should be in every decent RPG.\nSadly
votesTotal: there are basically no "flavor" dialogue options to go along with your character.\nYou can accept or refuse a quest
votesFunny: you can even choose whom you want to side with on multiple occasions
commentsCount: but you can only do it one way. The developers were reasonable enough to give the Hero a neutral attitude
column16: but the "role-playing" part suffers from this.\nEven if it wouldn't affect the actuall outcome in any way
column17: it'd be good if they gave us more dialogue choices.\n\nThe questing is fun at first
column18: but as you are nearing the end of the storyline
column19: it becomes a bit dull.\nThere are still many places to explore
column20: but you sort of don't care anymore. The side quests aren't bad
column21: they're just missing that little something
column22: the twist that would keep you interested.\nAs a part of your questing
column23: you can gain or lose reputation with multiple factions.\nThe only real benefit of having the max reputation with the factions
column25: is to be able to do their quests and advance in the story (their merchants also give you more money for the things you sell them
column26:
but earning money is incredibly easy in the game anyway).

Then there's the combat system.
You grab a weapon of your choice
column27: distribute some talent points (which you get for doing various stuff thorough the game) and start slaying whomever and whatever needs to be slain.\nAs you eventually grow stronger
column28: you'll start noticing that fighting is terribly repetitive.\nThere are monsters that require absolutely no effort whatsoever to slay
column29: and there are monsters that are still fairly easy to defeat
column30: but can kill you in one or two hits
column31: so you have to kite them.\nAnd then there are archers who are insanely annoying to fight if you don't have any range weapon. Luckily
column32: there aren't many of those.\n\nThe character models
column33: animations and the voice acting get criticised by almost everyone
column34: but I had no big issues with those.\nOn occasions
column35: the NPCs do sound a bit funny
column36: but it happens even in modern games. It's not as horrendous as people claim it to be.\n\nWhat I did have a big problem with
column38: was the lack of any sort of ending.\nAfter you have dealt with the bad guy in either of the two possible ways
column39: the game just returns you to the main menu. Just like that.\nNo epilogue
column41: no further info on the in-game events
column42:
not even a glimpse of the Big Bad's (dis)graceful demise... nothing.
Huge disappointment!


All in all
column43: it feels as if the developers implemented a whole lot of great ideas
column44: but none of them got enough attention to fulfil its potential.\nTwo Worlds  is still a pretty fine game
column45: really worth your time  if you enjoy RPGs. It's just not as great as it could have been.\n"

reviewText:
I thought I'd give this game a try even though plenty seem to find it terrible and unfortunately I have to agree.
This game is very outdated with ugly graphics and atrocious voice acting. Nothing managed to grab me and want to keep playing, story seems boring and cliche.

I normally try to play a game for at least 10 hours before writing a review, but the voice acting immediately put me off, sounds very robotic with no emotion behind the words, sounds like someone is bored and just reading the lines half heartedly straight off the bat.
The default controls are horrible as well, space for action and e for jump.

At least you can change it. Though I could not map shift to anything at all and trying to map the tilde key just resulted in opening a dialogue function.

Character creation is extremely limited, you can only play as a male and change his hair and features a tiny bit.

I do not need to play much at all to decide that I really hate playing this game. It's terrible in every way. Talking to NPC's is like a form of torture, listening to dialogue that sounds like someone is very bored makes me want to mute the sound.

A waste of time to play such a bad game when there are heaps better games I can spend my time playing. I only have playtime more than an hour as I was trying to get all the card drops.

But if you feel the need to give it a try maybe get it on a sale. But to me this game is not worth playing even if it was free.
I'd rate it 4/10 as it is not a joy for me  to play at all.

reviewText: Two  Worlds is a third person medieval RPG with outdated, ugly graphics. The voice acting is atrocious and the music forgetable. Your character can only be male, with very little customization. Its unbalanced and glitchy, with the horses having pathing issues constantly. The quest tracker is confusing, with no clear path to take or who to talk to, to progress in the story. That said, the story seemed boring, pointless and cliche'. The clunky controls are horrible, not the regular space for jump its 'e' and space is for action O.o. with the exception of the mouse in the easy, unrewarding battles. Spells in the game feel weak and unaffective. Its obviously geared more towards being an MMORPG. It has Reality Pump DRM and you have to input a key and activate before you can play the game. They want your name, address, telephone number and e-mail address. It seemed extremely over the top intrusive considering its on Steam and I'm not going to play the multiplayer part. I would recommend playing Skyrim instead.

reviewText: I wanted so badly to like this game. and I do. Though just slightly. It can be an enjoyable game. But there are many many many flaws. The biggest ones, are that the voice acting is abysmal. by far the worst ive ever heard in a game. The missions = go here talk to this person, then go here and talk to him, then go here and talk to her, and kill the same enemies every 20 feet or so. and its hard to figure out what youre supposed to do too. And the combat is bad. Not the worst mind you, but very bad. it consists of mashing the LMCB over and over and over while he spins the sword in front of you. It only flat out sucks when you try to kill an archer cause they run from you and chasing them is annoying as ♥♥♥♥. I wont list anything positive about this game. ill simply say this: There are better simillar games out there. some for the same price. Get dragon age, the witcher, dark souls, dragons dogma, or even fable over this game. unless you get it on sale for like $1.25 like i did. Unlike every other steam reviewer, i wont say that this game sucks. its simply inferior and falls into the shadow of much better open world RPGs. Rest assured that it isnt the worst open world RPG. that honor goes to risen 3. Cant decide between giving this game a 5/10 or a 5.5/10, But what i can decide on is that even though i got *some* enjoyment, i doubt many other gamers would, so i cant recommend this game to the general gaming public. Pick this up if its on sale for less than $2 or if youre just an RPG junkie like me.

reviewText: Awesome roleplaying game great graphics and epic story. The beginning is very hard you have to take your time and build up be patient, dont dive into combat or you die. learn the jump back system for defense. The horse riding is better than any rpg ive played for realism, you can shoot your bow while riding horses. The combat system is very fun once you get comfortable with the way your character moves. THere is an ingenious way to stack equipment so nothing gets wasted and items lvl as they are stacked into eachother. There are hours and hours of content and side stories. The magic system is fantastic. This was due to buggyness rated as one of the worst RPGs but infact i find its one of the best RPGS now with the patching. I prefer this game over oblivion 10 to 1. The characters are more robust. Some people complain about the voice acting but its appropriate for the setting the old english. Also its nice to hear your character talk instead of read what he says as a mute as in most games.  There is plenty of element of exploration. This is a recommended must buy for anyone who likes skyrim,oblivion, gothic or any open world RPG 3rd person games. Also this game has some of the best looking armor sets ive ever seen in a game and the most veriety of weapons and items in any game to date.

reviewText:
Don't play this game,its a waste of time.

+Open World
+Good soundtrack overall
+Dialogues are pretty good even with secondary characters
+System combat can be fun
+Horses
+No class,you can do what ever you want
+multiples cities(impressive for such a old game
+a pure freedom of action from the start of the game
+I kinda like these kind of graphics
+the ambience too

now for the bad

-the difficulty is crazy and not understandable,let me just say that the final boss don't damage you if you have a end game stuff but a random knight can one shot you,you probably see what i mean.
-Artistic direction is random af
-Lore too
-Story is awfully bad and really short(its like 10 quests i think?)
-Melee weapons are really bad in this game
-A LOT of useless and not fun side stuff,like random dungeons with extremely difficult monsters to fight,orc camps,etc
-EXTREMELY repetitive,don't expect things to append you will do the same things from the start to the end and like me probably's gonna get really annoyed after a dozen of hours
-Really,really really bugged,lot of quest i couldn't finish because of that
-The females character have the worst modelization i've ever seen in a game before.
-Stealth and lockpicking skill are bugged,even if pnj are not around you'll get spotted,don't ask me why...
-Melee fighting skills are bugged too and really useless when fighting.
-The last cinematic of the game is probably the most random thing you will ever see(+no credits)

There's probably things i forgot but that should be enough.


I enjoyed the game at first and hated it at the end,please pass your way.

reviewText:
Out of the 360, gog.com and now this version that I own I'm impressed.

Not with the gameplay or the story cause its all junk that I love for some dumb reason, but the stability. For what ever reason the Steam version of this game runs so smooth I forget that this game was notorious for choppy framerates, sluggish gameplay and other major bugs. The only issues I've had is with the controls which seem to be very MMORPG like (I've only played maybe 3 of em).

When I don't have to have a second pause every four hundred feet and several massive glitches in a fight, I am so happy. When I can just run cross country at a decent clip and not feel like I'm slogging through mud when walking across a grassy field, I am so happy.

If you want to explore the Oblivion killer" that wasn't
date: check out this title.\n\nThe gameplay is simple
recommended: just three canned animations for hand to hand combat. Using bows is damn near impossible for how long it takes to draw a bow and land an attack when your range is not even remotely realistic. Now
hoursPlayed: the majick system is neat and the other thing that really sticks out is the creepy incest laden story with the sister. Yes

reviewText:
Just no.

Got it a really good discount hoping that it would help kill a few hours exploring a new world? And was I in for a disappointment? It's just bad. I could barely go through an hour before I found out how to get out of the game, enter my Steam library and choose the delete option.
Strangest of all is that now, I can place a single thing that turned me off from this game. There is just this overwhelming distaste hanging around it that is the result of so many things and issues. To name a few - the combat system, the dialogs, the atmosphere of the world, the menus, the in-game HUD, the combat! Well you get the idea.
If you are placed with the choice between spending a couple of pounds for this thing" and buying a cheeseburger - go for the burger

reviewText:
Two Worlds is a lot of fun if you enjoy RPG based games. The single player mode is my favorite & if you have the time to invest in playing it & questing I think you will really enjoy it. If your looking to buy it to play with others I would suggest that you save your money & find another game where there are more players. The top amount of people I have ever seen online at one time was like maybe 4 but that was well over 6 months ago. Last week I say 2 players but they didn't speak & didn't seam interested in doing anything other then running around the lobby area where you wait to join games.

Its a great game!
Its worth the money if you buy it to play alone!

reviewText:
The voice acting in this game could use some minor tweaking. I wonder if the devs have ever gave an explanation why it was so rough. It is the most... let's say peculiar voice acting I have ever encountered in a game.

Some impressive stuff:

The weather. Especially the fog, also the fact that  your character reacts to the weather changing.

Loads are super short, the map is open and you can just go inside peoples houses and ♥♥♥♥ without entering a loading screen like in Skyrim

The game remembers locations of slain mobs and remembers where you stored your crap in a box.

The performance, great fps count all across the board.

Some constructive criticism:

-The game is good but next time try adding someting cool like:
Soldiers
Machineguns
Rocket Launchers
Sniper Rifle
Tanks

Thanks!
voteText: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I finished the Epic Edition on DVD, then rebought it on Steam. I'm not a huge fan, but when a game is as universally panned as this one, I guess I need to make a point and reaffirm that some people will enjoy it.

Yes, it's a low-budget game, yes it has bugs (what open world RPG doesn't?), but it also has one of my best memories as a gamer: I discovered by myself that I could accumulate weapon merges, and ended up a kill machine that could one-shot everything in its path -- all within the constraints of the game, rather than through the use of cheating.

Abusing a game's mechanics is usually reserved to good, hardcore gamers. It's nice for once that a game could be abused by a more casual gamer.

(Also, an Eastern 'area' in a serious med-fan setting? It's so messed up it's hilarious. You just can't hate that game.)

reviewText:
I picked this game up in an RPG bundle on Bundle Stars for 5 bucks (As I'm writing this, that bundle is still  available.) I actually bought the bundle for Two Worlds II, but I figured if I played that one first, I would never go back and play this one, so I decided to play TW first.
Perhaps it is because of this that through the whole game I had a feeling of wanting to just get it over with. At the beginning of the game I was getting killed by everything, and I just wanted to get it over with, then I got a little stronger and acquired some better gear, but I really just wanted to get it over with. Then I finally did get it over with, and I looked back on the 20 hours I spent on the game and thought “well, I’m glad that’s over.”

I did miss out on the finer parts of the story due to skipping a LOT of dialogue because the voice acting is laughable and the on screen text is an odd “period appropriate” font which is hard to read.
(This obviously was before the world realized that fantasy RPGs don’t need to have period-appropriate gothic fonts and HUDs with ornamental metal decorations around the mini-map and bars, and where the menus look like scrolls/notebooks)

But what the main storyline boils down to is basically a series of fetch quests, to acquire the different parts of an artifact which will help something something the tomb of an orc god something something the main characters sister something something bring the god back something something. It's not very interesting, but it's not horridly boring.

As I said, the main story is just some fetch quests. For me this just meant running past a bunch of enemies, grabbing the artifact piece, and running like hell to the nearest exit. Do this a few times, bring them all together, fight the bosses, game over.
BUT there are also a slew of side missions to enjoy and different factions to be a part of. I chose to help out the necromancers and the merchants guild, but there are other groups.


The combat is alright with me, but it’s nothing special. For me it was equal parts slashing away with a weapon and pausing to switch spells. Not as stiff as, say, an Elder Scrolls game, with Two Worlds featuring automatic aiming and quick access bar which I never actually learned to customize except for the spells. Though the system was certainly not as entertaining as, say, the first Witcher.

As for the enemies on which you will be employing your combat, I thought there was a good diversity!  Though the RPG staple, “giant rat”, did not seem to appear (or I just didn’t notice) there are some quite cool enemies to do battle with. You have your standard wolves, skeletons, orcs, and bears, but also ghouls, zombies, dead knights and a  slew of others, all of which fight in different ways. There are creatures unique to different terrain, which is cool, and there are massively overpowered beings such as golems and hell lords (yes, HELL LORDS) walking around like they own the place. Overall, I was happy with the diversity of enemies. However, the minor boss battle at the end was an hour of me spamming the mouse button, and I hate that, though that may have something to do with me rushing though the game and getting to the boss before being properly leveled.

I’m not going to talk about the magic or leveling system because I didn’t put a lot of time into it, seeing as I was breezing through the game.

But, of course, average mechanics can be made up for with a good story and atmosphere right? Well let’s talk about both of those.

Story: It’s fine. It was underwhelming for me because, as is the case with these RPGs, the fate of the world was at stake, but I didn’t really care what happened to the characters in this world, because none of them were interesting or endearing. There’s something close to characterization in the relationship between the hero (you) and his sister, but it’s not really that engaging.

Atmosphere: The world looks quite good. When you pop into first person view and look around, there are a lot of pretty landscapes to behold. All types of environments are represented here (Glaciers, fields, deserts, bamboo forests, lava-pits, big cities, small villages), and they all look pretty great, but they are sometimes inexplicable. A desert will abruptly turn into a field, and other things of the like. But though these landscapes are pretty, they are also quite empty. There are many expanses of wilderness which don’t have any interesting features, NPC’s or enemies. Overall, the atmosphere is of a world which is interesting, but it does not make me want to BE there, which is what I look for in an RPG world.

Anyway, though my review is negative, I wouldn’t say that this is a horrible game. If you can get it in a bundle, as I did, it’s probably worth a play through, but only if you’re into the genre.

reviewText:
The game starts out as a fun hack and slash game, but soon the limited story, near no choice, repetative encounters(oh look, yet more wolves waiting to get oneshot), and POOR COMBAT MECHANICS become obvious.

Lots of item variety and looks, at the cost of any substance or depth to them, just numbers.  Magic being limited to 3 spells set up at a time makes it near unusable, trainers being often hidden(archery comes to mind), to the point where initially only melee is viable at the start.  30 levels in(and 10 hours) swapped to magic with gear to match.  total headache, much weaker then melee.

But then, even melee, apart from the passive skills, you are often swarmed with enemies, and often end up knocked down, or going 2hander for the aoe.

Alchemy hands down sucks in this game, with so much wasted potential.

Was fun for 5 hours, then it slowly went downhill.

Would not recommend.  Go play gothic or, (more similair) risen or something.

reviewText:
I didn't even get past the main menu.

Firstly, the game would CTD on startup until I got an old PhysX driver from the Nvidia website.

Then the in-game cursor was stuck in place, but I could (extremely inconsistently) move an invisible one around. I tried looking for solutions on forums, but none of them worked. The one which would likely have helped (disabling hardware cursor in the options menu, it helped in the sequel) was unusable, because even after about 3 minutes of trying, I wasn't able to click the interface tab with the erratic invisible cursor.

Open world RPGs are notorious for being buggy, but I don't recall ever playing one where even the main menu was completely broken.

Combined with a registration DRM, which pretty much asks you to fill out a resume, I have decided this game wasn't worth the hassle. Fortunately, I got it in a bundle, otherwise I would have been really mad. Buy this game at your own risk.

reviewText:
Utter Unplayable Garbage.

Which is too bad, because it really does have potential. All the RPG elements are there, and the game tries to give you freedom in your choices, which is also great. There's a ton of armor sets, and the map is frigin' huge.

That's all well and good, except it was all programmed by monkeys with keyboards.

The combat...oh my lord the combat is horrendous. Seriously, if you're gonna make a dodge mechanic, can I please control the direction in which I dodge? Remember MOrrowind combat? Yeah even this is 10 times worse than that. The visuals are gross, pixel-y, and look like a bad photoshop filter.

Horse combat!? Im my MMO, oh please tell me they at least got that right...
Nope. The horse combat is ♥♥♥♥♥♥. The horse doesn't control well, and just makes you feel like an idiot charging into a group of enemies.

I am gonna play Two Worlds 2 and hopefully find some redemption for this production team. If they were smart, they fired the old team and got a new one. I am really glad I only paid 4.00 USD for the whole package.

reviewText:
This game was nothing but problematic for me.
I had to install a special driver to get it to play, then wrestle the online authentication a few times, then I crashed whenever I changed the graphics settings to 1920x1080.

reviewText: Great game. Had it on windows XP and it works great. Got it on steam now for my new PC, but it refuses to work on windows 8.1 pro. Honestly, I'm having a hard time recommending this game on Steam, since the problem seems to be the Reality Pump DRM system, which locks up the game BEFORE i have a chance to enter the game's serial. If this single problem can be solved, either by Valve or by Reality Pump, so their DRM actually WORKS instead of locking up the game, then i'll be more than happy to revise this recommendation.\n\nPlease, do not be mistaken, the game is great, just this problem is stopping me from enjoying the game on my new PC.

reviewText:
Originally got this game to play with a friend. Was able to start up the game with no problems. Registration to start the game was not such a big deal as many people have made it out to be. I can not mention anything of the singleplayer as I have not tried any of that. However with multiplayer out of the three available servers that are up, only one of them is working and its a EU server. From there the population of the server is near dead being at the most I have seen around being ten or less people.

From there trying to connect with my friend to begin a game together became the problems. Both of us can start up and host a game but neither of us could ever join the other. We have tried every recommended step such as ports, dropping firewalls, bypassing routers, etc. Sadly I discovered that many others have had the same results with no solution.

If your looking to enjoy this game with a friend, sadly its a complete risk if it is going to work or not for you. I do not recommend this game on its multiplayer fuctions.

reviewText: Ive been looking for a game to play with a couple friends so when I saw this had multiplayer yea I had no problem paying 5 bucks for it, especially after reading the reviews. The combat is awful, the enemies are incredibly hard, the animations really throw me off, the camera sucks, the dialog kills me to hear, and so on. The game does have an awesome amount of weapons and armor though. But the game just feels dead when I play it. The world feels sooo empty for an rpg. It kinda seems like someone was working on a rpg and they had an good idea but were like #@!% it I dont feel like touching up al the crappy stuff" I really wanna like this game and I feel like it has so much potential but I just cant. But for real dont believe all these reviews talking about it being like oblivion and gothic. Theres a reason you've heard all about The Elder Scrolls and you have no idea what Two worlds is besides the fact you saw it was 5 bucks on steam."

reviewText:
I've made a terrible mistake.

While it is true that I never actually PLAYED the game, the amount of trouble this POS game gave me to get it to actually work was supremely frustrating.  But then the real kick in the jewels is that everything about the game is atrocious.  The graphics, the voice acting, the pacing, the introductory narrative that would have been written better by a prepubescent child completely improvising what's supposed to be the beginning of a riveting adventure story.  The world and the conflict feels cliche and boring.  There was no real character customization beyond an insultingly negligible character skin selection.

I wouldn't recommend this game at all to anyone under any circumstances ever.  Unless you hate having fun.  In which case play up.

reviewText:
The game itself feels like an old version of Skyrim. However there are so many small things in that game that totally ruin the game experience.

For me it felt like the game didn't scale - like it was expecting you to throw  it away after an hour of gameplay.
I was a level 65 mage in the end. I had the best possible staff at around lvl 15...
Btw. you have 2x10 skill slots, but only 3 of them can contain spells. Most skills are pretty much useless. The AI could be tricked very easily. There were almost no items for high level characters - and the few which where there had the same stats as low level equipment.

I could go on about this, but I read that the second part is much better - so I am off to that one :P

reviewText:
First of all, I must say I paid 1 dollar for this game and was aware of what it was (played it some years ago), so I'm not really mad at it and I consider I'm objective.

The game isn't all that bad (it is bad, don't get me wrong). I start playing it in a Let's Play and it's fun to play, like a very bad movie is fun to watch.

The biggest issue with it is that it's almost unplayable. I had to install nvidia legacy drivers and reboot my computer to launch it the first time. Made 3 episodes of my let's play... Today I want to launch it again, but it doesn't want to :/

Also, when it's working, the game crashes a lot. For example I have to load my game while in window 800x600 mode (otherwise it crashes) and only when I'm in game I can go fullscreen with a higher resolution... The game made that easy since everytime I launch it, it's in window 800x600 mode again !

Also there's a very intrusive DRM that ask you where you live and stuff like that to activate the game. Apparently you can only install it on 3 different computers before having to ask the game staff to give you more activations. Unacceptable.

Concerning the game itself :

- The gameplay is kinda fun with some minor issues that stacked together ruins the game : you have to stand still to shoot arrows, melee combat is a random mess

- Horses are cluncky as ♥♥♥♥: it's like driving a big australian truck (you can almost hear the BIP... BIP... BIP when you move backward). You can use bows while riding but let's just say you don't want to do that :D

- It's not really fluid, voice acting is a disaster (on a furnitures commercial level), the story isn't good, etc etc...

Except if you plan to mock the game (and are okay to spend money for a game that will probably not run unless you spend 20-50 minutes on it), don't buy this piece of crap.

The game could be good if it was more polished and actually playable (the actual game would be very limit as an early-access title). What a waste :/

reviewText:

Play Dark Souls or Skyrim instead.

reviewText:
Alright, I'll start with saying this. I had fun with this game. So why do I not recommend it?  Because it is not for most people. I'm kind of weird, because I love a lot of games many people don't love, so I like this, but not many people will.

Here's why...

> There are a lot of bugs and glitches, and it is very unpolished. Plus, it is not optimized for newer hardware, and at 1080p, has a bunch of render issues, and is overall a drag to work.
> Many quests seem very underwhelming and, while it offers a lot of loot and rewards
date:
it doesn't seem that satisfying.
> This game is a beautiful open world tarnished by crappy writing, poor optimization, and broken gameplay.
> Gameplay is confusing and sometimes is broken.
> Voice acting is terrible. Don't even bother with it.

Overall, it is very dissatisfying. Like I said, I still had fun, and I got this for $1 in an India Gala Bundle with a bunch of other, better games, so I don't have any buyer's regret, but I do not recommend paying full price for this. At least, most people will find themselves dissatisfied.

reviewText:
This game is a disaster.  There are so many things about it that were executed poorly that I have trouble believing it's a finished product.  That said, there are a number of great seeds here, and if they fixed almost everything about the game, it could actually be enjoyable.

The voice acting is heroicly awful, it is visually appalling (even for its age), and the dialogue and story appear to have been written by my 8-year-old nephew.  The combat is stiff and impossibly diffucult, and they make traveling on foot pointless within the first hour of the game.  The only reason you should buy this game is so  you can understand that no matter how hard you try, at least you will not have been responsible for releasing this game.

It baffles me that it got a sequel, and baffles me more that the sequel might actually be good...

reviewText:
Get Oblivion rather, no seriously pay a little bit more and buy a FAR better game. I bought it a discounted price of $1.00 (coupon), still not worth the $1.00 I spent.

Graphics - Average for its time and size
Audio - Music - Not to bad
Audio - General - sub par
Voice Acting - Very BAD
Gameplay - Clunky, difficult to use and unintuitive
Story - *Only play two hours of the game* - Lacking

Good or unique parts-
- sort of a different approach to magic (not really but kinda)
Bad parts-
- Respawn system
- Horrible distribution of leveled mobs (all to high for any good reason)
- Poor skill selection

All in all I give this game a 1 out of 4

reviewText: This game is a downright failure. I have only had the Steam version for a little while; I paid a dollar for it, and I still feel like I was chumped for my money. reviewText:
From the screwing around to get the game to run to the downright stupid bindings and derpy looking animations this game just isn't worth money, instead of backwards and jump being jump backwards it has it's own bind where it shouldn't jump by default is E and interact is space while jump back is Q and so on when the mouth moves in conversation it is entirely out of sync and half the time doesn't move.

Oh and on top of that you have to waste time registering to access everything and can't copy/past the required code as it only pastes the first box... so yeah pretty poorly done thing, also steam this came out in 07 not 09...

The idea seems alright and it could have been a great game if some people who understood syncing and normal controls had got behind it, if it was redone by a dev who knew what they were doing it could be pretty good.

Added later:
The most poorly thought out thing with this game appears to be the quest setup as you get quests that you shouldn't have at certain points as required npcs are yet to be spawned in the world, some quests get stuck in the log as completing them in alternate ways through finishing quests that are tied to them doesn't register them complete (and again with npc quest issues related npcs may have never even spawned) and hell the quest that the Ashos guard gives you seems to be unable to be completed if you do as the blacksmith asks as the mayor seems to never spawn... so yeah it could have been a good game but the good half of the devs couldn't keep it from ending up both derpy and rather broken.

reviewText: I cannot recommend this game. I want to, very badly, but I cannot. Yes, even for $2.50, not worth it. The Last Remnant is cheaper and a better challenge, no lie. This is despite it being RECOMMENDED as a OS by STEAM. Fail. After the first fifteen minutes was scouring the internet for information I fnally got into the game. Two Worlds was made in 2007, so I forgave the awkward character creation system and lackluster options in hair styles and colors. Even the great for its time" graphic rendering. For me

reviewText:
Game crashes on start-up, so you have to go to another website and downlaod a driver. After that you have to manually enter your keycode, then they want you to register it (name, address, phone #, birth date, etc.... yeah right, I'm going to give them all that). And to top things off, it won't acivate. Games like this just ruin your day.

After another 5 attempt to get it to activate, I come to find out that you can only play multiplayer on European servers, American ones are shut down. I may have seen at any one time up to a whole 3 other people playing it. It suffers from terrible lag.

When playing multiplayer, you have to finish all the quests in one sitting, otherwise it restarts all over again.

'Oh your connection timed out, too bad, time to start over from the beginning again.' But on the plus side you keep everything you got from the previous session.

Co-op is pretty much non-existant, all you share is exp and gold. And all monsters are always in groups of 3.

No penalty for dying and I died alot.

And to think I bought this game just for the multiplayer portion of it.
voteText: 11 of 28 people (39%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A relatively old game, finished it for the second time now, and enjoeyed it more than the first time.

What I like
+ good graphics for the main character ( the armor & weapons look awasome )
+ pretty good graphics for the environment
+ action oriented rpg, you don't get to just walk around, you find stronger monsters everywhere
+ motivational AI: you find monsters that kill you in one shot at first! So you grow stronger, until, in the end you feel like a god ( you fight the same monster, 5 - 10 in number )
+ no puzzles ( i don't like them )
+ simple but fun combat and spells
+ stacking armors/weapons of the same type ( if you find armors/weapons of same kind you can just combine it for something stronger )

What I didn't like
+ if you use a horse, quick save because you could get stuck in some textures ( rarely but happens )
+ awkward control with the horse
+ some animations could have been better
+ real doge ( you have a back dodge ), but a dodge controlled with arrrow keys makes the fight more dynamic
+ end game too easy. I was a god in the end, pre-boss took 5 max hits, and boss 2  hits.
+ game crashes ( very rarely but happens ). I suggest to use quick save.

I recommend the game if:
+ you are an action RPG lover ( dislike rpgs with quests where you get 3 flowers, etc )
+ can make a compromise with some elements of graphics/animations
+ don't like puzzles, because there are none in this game

Otherwise, go and get it, you'll have a lot of fun

Cheers
voteText: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Very poor game. Hardware-wise it stutters on 9 out of 10 machines you play it on. In terms of gameplay. the world is very open, yet you still feel boxed-in. Horse riding is a total pain in the ♥♥♥, they seem to have their own agenda and don't all-in-all, it doesn't work very well. They bump into invisible walls and take themselves up weird routes.

Combat feels completely devoid of consideration, you just repeatedly LClick. You're stunlocked while attacking, so attack once more than you want to (which is way too easy to do) and you'll take hefty punishments from the thousands of mobs you pull just walking through the wilderness. It feels way more like an MMO that only you are playing rather than an RPG - there are far too many mob encounters, meaning it takes forever to get anywhere if you're not the kind to just pull a trail of creeps around with you.

The voice acting is ridiculously bad, and the dialogue is cringeworthy. I've played some bad RPGs, but this one takes the cake.

I hear the second one's better, though.

reviewText: I could talk for hours about how terrible this game is (the awful enemy AI, the horrible horse riding mechanics, the overly large mostly dead world, the terrible combat, the atrocious writing which barely makes sense....I could go on), but instead I'm just going to describe one quest to you. It pretty much sums up what's wrong with this game in a nutshell and might be the single worst designed RPG quest I've ever encountered.\n\nSo, some guy in a random village wants a curse of  fish monsters eliminated so he tells you to go speak to a Wizard---who sends you to a villager, who sends you to a lady, who sends you back to the villager, who sends you to the Wizard, who sends you to the villager, who sends you to the Lady, who sends you to the Wizard, who sends you back to the lady, who then kills herself for some reason, then you have to go back to the Wizard to finish. Yeah, so basically 20+ minutes of running back and forth listening to ♥♥♥♥ dialog. And there are more quests like this!

reviewText:
Don't even know where to begin with this game... It was my childhood favourite game and i loved every single aspect of it, and i had the game from day 1 so to all the people saying there's glitches well you shoulda played back then!:D
This game doesn't need an amazing set of voice actors or incredible HD graphics because it does what all old school games do.. blows your mind with amazing combat and immersion.
Not to mention it has so many elements to it:
-You're walking down the road and stumble across a bandit camp.
-They block your path and demand gold.
- (low level character) tells them they should leave before they get hurt and they laugh before charging you
-(High level character) doesn't even need to tell them to leave as they're already fleeing for their lives
- after scaring or killing the bandits you pillage their camp and find a master locked chest
- spends 5 lockpicks trying to open but to no avail
- gets rewarded for reaching a lockpicking goal and receives 1 skill point
- uses said skill point to level up lockpicking skill
- Attempts lock with last lockpick and opens chest first time
- about to loot chest and gets chased away by bounty hunters that have been set upon you by a regions guard
- get's one shot because hunters are OP
- respawns close by and runs for the hills where you find the bandits camped that you scared earlier
- befriends the bandits and returns to that master locked chest
- your bandit friends help you take out the bounty hunters smoothly
- you are accepted by your new bandit friends and live out your days drinking ale and pillaging

10/10 still a better RPG than skyrim

reviewText: My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through. I agreed. At 28
date: I have never touched a cigarette. I must say
recommended: I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it
hoursPlayed: because this game gave me cancer anyway.\n"

reviewText: Tworlds: Epic Edition is actually a fun game. I came into the game knowing that it was not the best game, not what it was hyped up to be, and I enjoyed it. It is much better on pc than it was on console. There is no combat lag that I could tell, and the combat reminded me of dark souls which I had a ton of fun playing.\n\nThe game is only $3 on the Black Friday sale and is a great buy for anyone who is into RPGs and is looking for another one to add to their collection. The game has its bugs and glitches, but if you can look past them I know everyone will enjoy the game. The best part about knowing that it is a bad game is that you can laugh at stuff that happens like the dialogue and some of the combat mechanics and noises.

reviewText: Great game ! Right up there with elder scrolls. I like Two Worlds  better than oblivion and equal with morrowind. The graphics are a bit dated but not that bad - like xbox 360 era graphics. Its a little slow getting started but you level fast so the talent tree will have you growing more powerful in no time. im level 29 at the moment and there are still areas in the game i will not survive. I think the main story is good and i enjoy the side quests/stories as well. lots of reviews are complaining about the voice acting....its not that bad at all. ive definitely heard worse !   I highly recommend this game i got in in a package deal  Two Worlds collection" im glad i played this first before jumping right into the more modern Two Worlds 2. its really a great adventure worth playing. if you like elder scrolls type games you wont want to miss this.\n\nThe only thing that had me frustrated at first is the registration.  If you have a PC that has onboard graphics and hgh powered video card it will probably auto run the game to the onboard if its decent ( i have HD 4600 which is impressive for onboard ) anyway when i tried to force my high powered video card to run the game
date: the game thought i was trying to register the same game code on a different computer and wouldnt allow me to log in. so make sure you force the correct video card to run the game before you register

reviewText:
I didn't understand what people were trying to say in their reviews when they said that this game was flawed, but enjoyable. i get the concept of 'so bad they're good' movies, but thought the concept didn't apply to video games. This game changed my mind. I don't have any long-lasting great nostalgic love for this game, but I do like it, not joking. There are so many things wrong with this game, my first impression was awful - mostly due to the overly-invasive registration garbage, stiff combat, a glitchy map system and an undescriptive quest log. But the cheesy cornball acting and questing for loot kept me going.

Don't get me wrong, this isn't a hidden masterpiece. This isn't a fulfilling RPG experience on-par with the Elder Scrolls - despite numerous quotes to the contrary - but if you don't take it too seriously you might have some fun riding through forests cutting down orcs for their pocket change.

I do think this game is more worthy of play than it's successor, as TWII lost the charm of the original and somehow made the controls, map and quest log even worse.

reviewText:
One of the few games I have ever played that manage to make mage characters both vulnerable and also crazy powerful.  (Basically only games based on older D&D rules (such as Baldurs gate) have done similar, at least in my experience.)

Also your character is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ fantastic at times and is voiced by the most fitting voice imaginable.


The gear upgrading system is such a pain as to effectively unusable, but for a full mage/mage-warrior/mage-theif equip upgrading is unnessecary.  Also from what little gameplay I have had as a pure warrior/pure theif kind of char, they seem remarkably weak, but that could just be me being ♥♥♥♥.

reviewText: I know this got bad reviews and a lot of people hate it. It is a glorified hack and slash in an open world. I have always had a lot of fun with it though. I like the alchemy that uses rare ingredients to add permanently to your characters stats. I like picking an armor and a weapon and finding as many copies as possible to boost them. The voice acting and copywriting is pretty bad, but the premise is ok. The graphics are not the greatest but are not as bad as some people say. To me they don't have to be picture realiztic for a game to be immersive...but then I did play Zork at maximum verbosity back in the day so maybe I'm used to using my imagination.\n\nBottom line. I have fun with this. I have replayed it several times over the years. And I paid 99 cents for it on Steam. There's no down side there.

reviewText:
The games rather retro, the voice acting/script is horrid - not so much the voices as the script they are forced to follow. Ugh. But it distracts only a little. The controls are a bit odd, but thankfully you can customize some. There's a hotbar, but the F7 one is set, use one of the others to customize your own way. The storyline is playable, there's plenty of freedom to roam about. But make sure that you can deal with the wildlife... they tend to see you as something to kos if you are anywhere near them.

Take the time to get the feel of fighting, it's not just a stand there and hit type of game. You need to move or you'll go down will little effort on the attacker's part. Upgrade your items as often as you can, grab what you can brew and make sure to be careful what you put together when your experimenting. There's all sorts of things you can make...

All in all, it's not a bad game, rough sure... but not bad. There's no comparing it to today's games, since it was made some time ago. But I don't think it got the attention it should have when it came out. There are lots of forgotten gems like this one out there. The new one Two Worlds 2 picks up some time after this one ends...

I started playing it, but I wanted to find out the backstory to it. That's why I'm playing this one. Hope that you'll give both of the games a chance. I'm glad I did... even though I'm not really one for retro games.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
First off you should be informed about some things.

This game is really ♥♥♥♥ing fun, but that doesn't make it good compared to most other RPGs.

This game has a ton of game-breaking bugs that I as a gamer choose to ignore because quite blatantly I do not play this game for the story, the quests, or the combat; the things that the bugs affect most.

Instead, I chose to make my own goal of exploring the really awesome environment and acquring the most badass looking loot I could buy/find.

In my eyes this game isn't really an RPG, but a chance to take in the scenery. If you share my opinion then this game is worth buying. If not, I wholeheartedly understand because it is definitely not good in terms of being a story-compelling and character progressive RPG.

reviewText:
Probably one of the worst games I have ever played in my life. Its kind of like Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion... if Oblivion was a broken turd of a game.

Pros:
- It's so bad it's actually funny.
- It technically qualifies as a game.
- The DRM is terrible and can stop you playing the game after changing your computer hardware three times.
- You can choose not to buy this terrible game.

Cons:
- It's so bad.
- It's not a game you should ever play.
- You have to actually pay money for this thing (frankly, the devs should be paying you to play it).
- There is no way to get back any time wasted playing this game.

Final verdict?
10/10 IGN.

reviewText: Tworlds: Epic Edition is actually a fun game. I came into the game knowing that it was not the best game, not what it was hyped up to be, and I enjoyed it. It is much better on pc than it was on console. There is no combat lag that I could tell, and the combat reminded me of dark souls which I had a ton of fun playing.\n\nThe game is only $3 on the Black Friday sale and is a great buy for anyone who is into RPGs and is looking for another one to add to their collection. The game has its bugs and glitches, but if you can look past them I know everyone will enjoy the game. The best part about knowing that it is a bad game is that you can laugh at stuff that happens like the dialogue and some of the combat mechanics and noises.

reviewText:
The games rather retro, the voice acting/script is horrid - not so much the voices as the script they are forced to follow. Ugh. But it distracts only a little. The controls are a bit odd, but thankfully you can customize some. There's a hotbar, but the F7 one is set, use one of the others to customize your own way. The storyline is playable, there's plenty of freedom to roam about. But make sure that you can deal with the wildlife... they tend to see you as something to kos if you are anywhere near them.

Take the time to get the feel of fighting, it's not just a stand there and hit type of game. You need to move or you'll go down will little effort on the attacker's part. Upgrade your items as often as you can, grab what you can brew and make sure to be careful what you put together when your experimenting. There's all sorts of things you can make...

All in all, it's not a bad game, rough sure... but not bad. There's no comparing it to today's games, since it was made some time ago. But I don't think it got the attention it should have when it came out. There are lots of forgotten gems like this one out there. The new one Two Worlds 2 picks up some time after this one ends...

I started playing it, but I wanted to find out the backstory to it. That's why I'm playing this one. Hope that you'll give both of the games a chance. I'm glad I did... even though I'm not really one for retro games.

reviewText:
First off you should be informed about some things.

This game is really ♥♥♥♥ing fun, but that doesn't make it good compared to most other RPGs.

This game has a ton of game-breaking bugs that I as a gamer choose to ignore because quite blatantly I do not play this game for the story, the quests, or the combat; the things that the bugs affect most.

Instead, I chose to make my own goal of exploring the really awesome environment and acquring the most badass looking loot I could buy/find.

In my eyes this game isn't really an RPG, but a chance to take in the scenery. If you share my opinion then this game is worth buying. If not, I wholeheartedly understand because it is definitely not good in terms of being a story-compelling and character progressive RPG.

reviewText:
I reviewed this a while back with as a joke but today i came onto steam only to it as the newest released game, I have no idea why this is considered new but what the hell it gives me the chance to review this horrible mess again.

Two Worlds is a western rpg that plays, sounds and looks like crap. It is perhaps the worst game i have ever completed and i have no intention to ever play it again.

The story is about a man who has lost his sister, shes kidnapped or something and it is your quest to glitch your way through twenty plus hours of running past things.

I created a melee fighter as i couldn't be arsed figuring out the magic system and as a melee guy i blessed with the good button of Q, a back-step. You see to fight in this game you hit then you jab Q. If you fail to jab Q you are probably dead as pretty much everything from a wolf to a demon-lord guy will one hit you. Now this may have been my own fault as around half way through i got extremely bored and stopped doing the side quests; they where boring.

There are a few moments in the game that really shine like the bit where you glitch your horse onto a teleporter and jab enter so you can take it with you in this massive boring landscape (Seriously the first horse teleport i manged to do was extremely satisfying). Or the bit where you take the final boss(apparently someone who everyone is afraid of) half way across the map in the hopes that you can find a bear to kill him cause you cant be arsed to spend another thirty minutes trying to get another quarter of his health down .

Overall, its a boring massive world with terrible dialogue and voice acting. The horrible combat system that is frustrating yet simple and the confusing and drawn out storyline make Two Worlds an experience that should only be touched when free and not really then.

reviewText: Yes this game is broken (Honestly could've done a much better job with it), but it is not a bad game. Very fun to run around and kill everything in the game(Within reason of course ~ Joke lol), and overall a fun grind'em up. The voice acting is an atrocity that kinda makes it a comedy more or less. So, with that in mind, it's like playing a comedic rpg where the story isn't super serious. But here's where it gets really good. This game has almost an ENDLESS amount to upgrading and leveling up and such. There really are few limits to what you can do when you want to upgrade your armor and such. There are a ton of weapons and armor, albeit with some similar designs, but nevertheless this game is quite a good play. Not I wouldn't recommend buying it market price, but when it is on sale for around 99 cents, you should take it up. Quite the good game to pass time.

reviewText:
Although at first glance this game seems quite lame, it holds hours of fun. At the start of the game things go a tad slow, you're just another average joe, and the tutorial is sub par. However, once you gain a few levels, and discover the inner workings of the game it becomes one of the best RPG experiences I've encountered.

Suggestions for your Enjoyment
-Magic is very weak early game. Build up your sword arm
-Alchemy is very useful, some ingrediants provide permenant bonuses (if it's a gem or mineral pair it with healing so you           don't get a magic dmg stone for your weapon
-Equipment that is the same can be combined into each other to make one better one ( two longswords? Now you have 1 better long sword)

reviewText: Own it on disc and played it for ages but didn't mind paying the £1.50 sale price rather than look for it in the cupboard to give it another go. The animations might be a bit ropey but the visuals aren't too bad. The combat could have been done better and feels a bit dated, using the bow is pretty poor, but if you can look beyond it's faults there is a huge game for the tiny price.\nAlways liked the way you can combine matching items to boost them up (mouse over them in the inventory and if they match they turn green, then just drag 'n' drop). I would suggest using the 'jump-back' key to avoid enemy attacks and survive combat for longer though, especially at the start, and carry a mix of slashing, piercing and bashing weapons with different elemental upgrades. Horses have their own inventory, just stand next to them and get the panel up, use these to solve your storage problems by gathering a few around a teleport site. Doing this and having different ones for different item types makes it easier to collect armour sets etc and to keep matching items to combine them.\nHuge world, loads of locations to discover, tons of loot, vast number of quests, hacking down creatures while on horseback, if you want an epic rpg experience and give it the chance it deserves you'll soon find yourself ignoring it's failings and find a good game, get it at sale price and you can't go wrong.

reviewText: Two Worlds Epic Edition (Two worlds 1) is a hidden gem. It is Well worth the sticker price of US $9.99 . Two Worlds Epic Edition plays allot like the Elder scrolls or the Torchlight games. In play style, Two worlds feels like a simplified mix of the two styles. The voice acting is quite good as is the writing and quests. Gold is plentiful, Alchemy is fairly easy, and crafting" is fairly easy. Inventory management is fairly easy suffering only from a few glitches common to most games - there never enough room and this detracts from gameplay. TW1 however makes it easy to teleport around to shops and sell your goods and get back to game play.\nTwo worlds 1 has its own small mod community over at www.insidetwoworlds.com/forumdisplay.php?f=3 IF you want to download one of the mods
date: I suggest using the Two world control panel - http://www.insidetwoworlds.com/showthread.php?t=26659 . TW also has a mod sdk and nice tools. TW1 really has not seen much mod authoring since about 2007-2008 and the forum while not deserted
recommended:
lacks the excitement you find in Torchlight or the Elder scrolls games. Using mods is optional in TW1 - its really a nice game on its own.

TW1 has a multiplayer mode I did not try.

So if you like adventure games
voteText: as part of the US$5 bundle and don’t feel badly if you pay full price since TW1 is well worth the US$9.99 sticker price!"

- You have to actually pay money for this thing (frankly, the devs should be paying you to play it).
- There is no way to get back any time wasted playing this game.

Final verdict?
10/10 IGN.

reviewText: I know this got bad reviews and a lot of people hate it. It is a glorified hack and slash in an open world. I have always had a lot of fun with it though. I like the alchemy that uses rare ingredients to add permanently to your characters stats. I like picking an armor and a weapon and finding as many copies as possible to boost them. The voice acting and copywriting is pretty bad, but the premise is ok. The graphics are not the greatest but are not as bad as some people say. To me they don't have to be picture realiztic for a game to be immersive...but then I did play Zork at maximum verbosity back in the day so maybe I'm used to using my imagination.\n\nBottom line. I have fun with this. I have replayed it several times over the years. And I paid 99 cents for it on Steam. There's no down side there.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Two Worlds is not the horrible game I was led to believe it to be. It's also not a good game in any respect. The game has some decent ideas, but in the end it fails on every front.

The graphics are a mixed bag; environments look decent considering the year the game was released (it looks very similar to the environments found in Oblivion, to the point where it almost looks plagiarized), the character models and effects however are disastrous, looking like upcaled 5th gen models running at 10 fps.

The sound fails in all respects. I can't think of a single track from the game. The only thing I can recall just a day after beating the game is the annoying low health sound.

The story premise starts interesting enough, but plays out extremely tediously and dull. The ending is the most uneventful I've ever seen in a game.

If you're a die-hard RPG player that has run out of other games to play during a dry spell, give this a try. Otherwise, stay far away and play another game for your RPG fix.

reviewText: Really fun games at first, until you realize that all the quests are the same, all the combats are redundance, and all the voice-acting are slowly driving you nut everytime you talk to an npc. The developers also didn't even bother putting a search system or anything that make items sorting easier. How the heck are you guys emphasizing the concept of alchemy and combining items so much when you don't even have anything that help maximize its capability. From the 30 hours I put in this game, I need to use 10 hours searching for every single duplicate item in my storage just so that I can combine them  in my inventory(yeah, not my storage but my inventory because the developers somehow couldn't manage to make them glow in the storage, idk). Overall, this is a mediocore rpg that you can play to pass your time while waiting for Dragon Age or Elder Scrolls or other triple A rpg games. Play it for a while then delete it once you reach the 20 hours threshold.

reviewText: Same as how Crash Time II is a poor mans Burnout, Two Worlds is a poor mans Oblivion. That being said it's not a bad game. It's got some really cool enviroments and a really nice sound track. Just like how Bioshock was the spiritual successer to System Shock, Two Worlds is the spiritual successer to Quest 64. reviewText: Can give you hours of entertainment, however, the amount of hours don't add up to finishing the game.  It get's dry and you feel like you are just grinding.  There isn't much evolution in combat, so it feels about the same later in the game as it does in the begining.  I find no advantage between classes.  If you can't swing a weapon (warrior), you aren't going to last long.  Magic doesn't do more damage, and I find it usually does significantly less.  Yes, there are places you can steal if you are a thief, but making money isn't hard, so you are giving up your ability to fight by building the steath skills.  Storyline isn't very complex.  Quests from one dude feel about the same as a quest from anyone else.  Quests don't add much to the game's feel either.  You just have an alternate reason to run around and kill everything you see.  I rate this as a good buy when it is on sale for 80 percent off or more, but don't expect a bethesda game here.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
It reminds me a LOT of Gothic 3 in all the good and bad things about it. It has a huge open world, no monster respawning, even the leveling system and the effects of some spells just remind me of Gothic 3. But it just made the same mistakes as the creators of the third Gothic, it just somehow lacks in storytelling and I just cannot get immersed into its world, maybe it is just something that happens with such a huge world. Personally that was also the case for me with Oblivion and Skyrim.

<beginning_of_a_personal_nostalgic_note>
I really miss the days of playing Gothic 1 and 2, because they had relatively small worlds and a band of NPC friends (funny I still remember even some of their names after over 8 years - like Diego, Fester, Milten, Gorn).
And it is not just because of the voice acting, let's be honest the voice acting in gothic 1 and 2 wasn't perfect.
</end_of_personal_nostalgic_note>

Yeah and as for the weapons it reminds me a bit of Borderlands. There is a ton of weapon and armor models with more or less randomly generated stats + enchantments, so the final effect is, that there is practicaly an infinite number of their variations. That turns most of the progress into that weapon-stat game, where you will never have the best possible weapon or armor, there is always something stronger that can be generated by the all-powerful RNG.

Verdict:
I think the mixed" summary that it has as of the day I wrote this review fits it well. So if you liked Gothic 3 get it
date: you will not be dissapointed it is almost the same in terms of gameplay. So overall I recommend it on a (-50% or -75%) sale."
helpfulPercent: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This is a Review for the PC Game Two Worlds The Epic Fail Edition

50 Cons :

1. ♥♥♥♥ Poor Animations.
2. ♥♥♥♥ Poor Voice Acting.
3. Horrible Dialogue.
4. Horrible game storyline.
5. Idiotic side quest storylines and downright illogical continuations.
6. Lame movespeed with no sprinting.
7. Mediocre character. Never felt like playing his role. Hes a jackass for all I care.
8. Couldnt select female character for some reason. I thought this was an RPG.
9. The towns at the beginning of the game have no women or children, they just have grown old men with lots of hair on chest.
10. Horse whistle sounds like bird chirping. It is what a sparrow sounds like, not a human being's whistle.
11. Horses move like cars, when they are running towards your whistle they slide towards you.
12. Turning around a horse is like turning around a car only difference being you are either on full speed or you STOP completely and move around then press forward.
13. Stiff horse animations get you stuck everywhere.
14. Horse combat is almost impossible to do right.
15. Sneaking is an active skill and not a character movement thing.
16. Combat is ridiculous.
17. Hit detection does not exist.
18. Protagonist's sister is the most unattractive female in all of Tamriel. (Because I bet nobody remembers what the world in Two world's is called)
19. More teleporters than in Portal 2. Even personal teleporters that are reusable and craftable via certain npcs.
20. Huge loads of points to spend on skills on level up.
21. Everything can be combined with everything and everything can be upgraded to the level of inifinity.
22. Combine 10 pearls with 10 Diamonds and you are invincible.
23. Way too many Armor and weapons that force you to change every once in 15 minutes.
24. Horrible Enemy AI.
25. Scripted Archers run away from you when you reach then but try to shoot you as soon as they are 5 metres away from you.
26. Archers take exactly 15 seconds to shoot one arrow.
27. Skeletons are mindless for real in this game and do nothing other than make you play dubstep in the background.
28. VERY Unbalanced ENEMY and NPCs.
29. ♥♥♥♥ Poor system of planting an auto target on everyone.
30. Similar clothing and same dialogues for 50% of the population makes me send a fireball to an auto targetted npc then realise he can kill me in 3-4 hits and I barely scratch him. So I die and resurrect like nothing ever happenned.
31. The game experiences 1 season per day.
32. Herbs are so common I can make my own RPG game by collecting them and planting them in it.
33. There are more wolves and boars in this game than any herbivore animal. I wonder how they survive in that kind of a food chain system.
34. The devs made 4 plant types, 3 trees, 2 grass models and exactly 2 shrubs and copy pasted it on the whole map a billion times.
35. Setting HDR to max gives lighting that makes no sense.
36. Stutters out of nowhere.
37. Magic is very underpowered early game.
38. The character plays the character of a self righteous bad-♥♥♥ wannabe that thinks he is above all.
39. Nonsensical terrain looping. Copy paste all over the big ♥♥♥ map.
40. No such thing as a mountain. Just hills and big rocks.
41. Automated lockpicking system based on probability.
42. Overused and few enemy types with zero behavior differences.
43. People use axes to chop the floor and shovels and sickles to chop trees. For some reason...
44. Horses wont teleport with you, cause they cant enter the teleporter along with you on their back because of model size collision.
45. Arrows fly everywhere except for the TARGET with no indication of wind speed and direction.
46. Character can pickup stuff midway while riding the horse but needs superhuman reflexes to achieve that.
47. Lurable enemies with HP/MP regenerating shrines right next to every fight.
48. NPCs cant be killed, guards cant be killed.
49. Bears are very stubborn creatures that dont even budge when you hit them with a sword, that is till they are dead ofcourse. Because you know, bears feel no pain.
50. BORING.

Can easily name 50 more but ... I got better things to do.

Pros :

1. GREAT GAME START MAIN MENU THEME SONG! Definitely gets you in for some RPG MOOD and then ... well thank you very much.
